revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox organization | image = AlexianenkloosterGentJoseph Van Haerde 7-10-2009 14-47-13.JPG | caption = Alexians [[monastery]] in [[Ghent]] ([[Belgium]]) on the former {{Interlanguage link multi|Oude Houtlei|nl}} by [[Joseph Van Haerde]] | motto = | formation = {{Circa}} [[Anno Domini|AD]] {{start date and age|1469}} | type = Lay Religious Congregation of Pontifical Right (for Men) | headquarters = [[Belgium]] | leader_title = Superior General | leader_name = Br. Lawrence Krueger, C.F.A. | main_organ = | name = Alexian Brothers | native_name = | size = | abbreviation = C.F.A. | founder = [[Fr. Dominicus Brock]] | website = {{url|alexianbrothers.org}} | membership = 80 members (3 priests) (2014) }}The '''Alexians''', '''Alexian Brothers''' or '''Cellites''' are a Catholic [[religious institute]] or [[congregation (Catholic)|congregation]] specifically devoted to caring for the sick which has its origin in Europe at the time of the [[Black Death]]. They follow the [[Augustinian]] rule.
==History== The Alexians trace their origin to the early 12th-century [[Beguines and Beghards|Beghards]], male counterparts of the [[Beguines and Beghards|Beguines]], [[layperson|laywomen]] who followed a devout style of life in a limited degree of common life. The men did not get much attention until they made a great contribution in history in the city of [[Mechelen]], in the [[Duchy of Brabant]] (in central [[Flanders]], now [[Belgium]]), some time in the 14th century, during the terrible ravages of the [[Black Death]]. Some laymen united under the guidance of a man named Tobias to succor the plague-stricken without taking any vows or adopting [[monasticism]]. One of their most obvious activities was caring for those stricken with the [[bubonic plague]], along with their families, and burying those who died. These laymen lived in little rooms or cells (from Latin "cella," a cell that gave rise to their early name of "Cellites").
The speculation that the name "Beghards" arose from supporting themselves by begging for food was dismissed by the [[Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition|''Encyclopædia Britannica'' Eleventh Edition]].
The plague victims became the outcasts of the society and were thrown outside the city walls, along with the other marginalized folk, to die. Moved by compassion, these laymen came together and vowed to take care of these victims who were abandoned by not only the state and the church, but also their families. Later on, the group attracted more men who chose to abandon their secular lives to live in community as brothers and to serve the needs of the poor. Eventually, the Catholic Church saw the utility of the brothers and invited them to be formally recognized as a religious group and subsequently gave them pontifical status. The brothers were associated with a chapel dedicated to [[Alexius of Rome]], who had served many years in a hospital at [[Edessa]] in [[Syria]], and they began to be called the Brothers at St. Alexius Chapel, a name that evolved into that of Alexian Brothers, their modern name.
=== Germany === The Brothers rapidly spread throughout [[Germany]], Brabant, Flanders, and other countries. They were also styled in [[Middle Dutch]] ''lollebroeders'' "mumbling brothers", or ''"Lollhorden"'', from Old {{lang-de|lollon}}, meaning "to sing softly," from their chants for the dead. This name was later adopted as a term of contempt, applied first to [[Franciscans]] and later to the heretical followers of [[John Wycliffe]].) The Alexians did not escape calumny and persecution, as demonstrated from the [[papal bull]] ''"Ad Audientiam Nostram"'' (2 December 1377) which [[Pope Gregory XI]] sent to the German bishops, especially those of [[Cologne]], [[Trier]] and [[Mainz]], forbidding annoyance of the "Cellites" and enjoining punishment for their persecutors. This was followed by Bulls of a similar tenor from [[Pope Boniface IX]] on 7 January 1396, [[Pope Eugene IV]] on 12 May 1431, [[Pope Nicholas V]] and [[Pope Pius II]].
In 1469, the [[motherhouse]] at [[Aachen]] voiced the general feeling of the Brothers in asking [[Louis de Bourbon, Bishop of Liège]], to raise that house to a [[convent]] of the [[Order of Saint Augustine]]. The request was granted, and in 1854 Father Dominicus Brock and five of the Brothers took the solemn vows of religious under the rule of St. Augustine. This step and the revised constitution of the [[Religious institute (Catholic)|religious institute]] were confirmed by [[Pope Pius IX]] on 12 September 1870.
=== Hospitals === In the early 20th century the Alexian Brothers had four hospitals in the United States. The first was built in [[Chicago]] in 1866; it was destroyed by the [[1871 Great Chicago Fire|Great Fire]], on 9 October 1871, and rebuilt the following year. The second, erected at [[St. Louis]] in 1869, covered an acre with its departments for the insane, nervous diseases, and inebriates. The third was in [[Oshkosh, Wisconsin]] and built in 1880. The fourth was built in [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]], on land given for that purpose by Right Rev. Bishop Wigger. Competent surgeons and physicians attended to the patients, and the Brothers nursed and did the housework of the hospitals.
Today, the Chicago hospital has become the Alexian Brothers Medical Center and Rehabilitation Hospital in [[Elk Grove Village, Illinois]], and the St. Alexius Medical Center and Behavioral Hospital, both in Hoffman Estates, Illinois. These also operate satellite centers and clinics around Illinois. In Missouri, Tennessee and Wisconsin the Alexians run a group of facilities, care systems, homes and communities all for older adults. The other hospitals have been sold or closed.
Bishop (later Cardinal) [[Herbert Vaughan]] of the [[City of Salford]], [[England]] invited the Alexians to take charge of a new home and hospital in his diocese, which led to their establishing themselves in England in June 1875. Dr Richard Lacy, [[Bishop of Middlesbrough]], secured them for his diocese in 1884. In 1885, the Brothers established a province of their institute and a novitiate in the [[United Kingdom]]. The latter, first attached to St. Mary's Convent, [[Newton Heath]], [[Manchester]], was later transferred to [[West Twyford]], near [[Ealing]], which the Alexian Brothers had purchased.
==Present situation== The Immaculate Conception Province (the American Province) sponsors [https://web.archive.org/web/20110212005104/http://www.alexianbrothershealth.org/index.aspx Alexian Brothers Health System], which provides services in acute care, residential elderly care, retirement centers, and AIDS ministry in [[Illinois]], [[Missouri]], [[Wisconsin]], [[Tennessee]], and also outside the USA in the [[Philippines]] and [[Hungary]]. On January 1, 2012 the Alexian Brothers Health System became part of St. Louis-based [[Ascension Health]], the nation’s largest Catholic and non-profit health system.{{Citation needed|date=November 2013}}
The contemporary British houses in [[London]] and [[Manchester]], as well as the Irish ones in [[Dublin]] and [[Limerick]], include facilities for the elderly sick and physically handicapped through a nursing home and Day Centre; an AIDS ministry; care and rehabilitation of homeless men; and support for people suffering from mental illness.
On the European continent the contemporary German branch has houses in [[Aachen]], [[Krefeld]], [[Kraiburg|Malseneck]], [[Münster]] and [[Twistringen]]. In Belgium they have centres in [[Boechout]], [[Tienen]], [[Grimbergen]] and [[Henri-Chapelle]], where they provide psychiatric services.
==Sources== *{{Catholic|wstitle=Alexians}} *{{Schaff-Herzog|title=Alexians|url=http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/encyc01.html?term=Alexians|volume=1|}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.alexianbrothers.org/ The Alexian Brothers International website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050408083206/http://www.alexianbrothers.org/english/history/history.html Alexian Brother facilities in the USA] * [https://www.webcitation.org/5kmWpmmiV?url=http://www.geocities.com/Athens/1534/ruleaug.html Text of the Rule of St. Augustine] ( ( 2009-10-25)
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2011}}

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Serotonin syndrome}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome | synonyms = Antidepressant withdrawal syndrome<ref name=TI2018>{{cite web |title=[112] Antidepressant Withdrawal Syndrome {{!}} Therapeutics Initiative |url=https://www.ti.ubc.ca/2018/07/23/112-antidepressant-withdrawal-syndrome/ |website=Therapeutics Initiative |accessdate=3 August 2018 |date=23 July 2018}}</ref> | image = | alt = | caption = | pronounce = | field = [[Psychiatry]] | symptoms = [[Flu-like symptoms]], trouble sleeping, nausea, poor balance, sensory changes<ref name=War2006/> | complications = | onset = Within 3 days<ref name=War2006/> | duration = Few weeks to months<ref name=Gab2017/><ref name=Dav2018/> | types = | causes = Stopping of an [[antidepressant medication]]<ref name=War2006/><ref name=Gab2017/> | risks = | diagnosis = Based on symptoms<ref name=War2006/> | differential = [[Anxiety]], [[mania]], [[stroke]]<ref name=War2006/> | prevention = Gradual dose reduction<ref name=War2006/> | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = 20-50%(with sudden stopping)<ref name=Gab2017/><ref name=Dav2018/> | deaths = }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> '''Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome''', also called '''antidepressant withdrawal syndrome''', is a condition that can occur following the interruption, reduction, or [[Medication discontinuation|discontinuation]] of [[antidepressant medication]].<ref name=War2006/> The symptoms may include [[flu-like symptoms]], trouble sleeping, nausea, poor balance, sensory changes, and [[anxiety]].<ref name=War2006/><ref name=Gab2017/><ref name=Dav2018>{{cite journal |last1=Davies |first1=J |last2=Read |first2=J |title=A systematic review into the incidence, severity and duration of antidepressant withdrawal effects: Are guidelines evidence-based? |journal=Addictive behaviors |date=4 September 2018 |doi=10.1016/j.addbeh.2018.08.027 |pmid=30292574}}</ref> The problem usually begins within three days and may last for several months.<ref name=War2006/><ref name=Dav2018/> Rarely [[psychosis]] may occur.<ref name=War2006/>
<!-- Risk factors and diagnosis --> A discontinuation syndrome can occur after stopping any antidepressant including [[Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor|selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors]] (SSRIs), [[serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor]]s (SNRIs), [[monoamine oxidase inhibitor]]s (MAOIs) and [[tricyclic antidepressants]] (TCAs).<ref name=War2006/><ref name=Gab2017/> The risk is greater among those who have taken the medication for longer and when the medication in question has a short [[half-life]].<ref name=War2006/> The underlying reason for its occurrence is unclear.<ref name=War2006/> The diagnosis is based on the symptoms.<ref name=War2006/>
<!-- Prevention and treatment --> Methods of prevention include gradually decreasing the dose among those who wish to stop, though it is possible for symptoms to occur with tapering.<ref name=War2006/><ref name=Wil2015>{{cite journal |last1=Wilson |first1=E |last2=Lader |first2=M |title=A review of the management of antidepressant discontinuation symptoms |journal=Therapeutic Advances in Psychopharmacology |date=December 2015 |volume=5 |issue=6 |pages=357–68 |doi=10.1177/2045125315612334 |pmid=26834969|pmc=4722507 }}</ref><ref name=Dav2018 /> Treatment may include restarting the medication and slowly decreasing the dose.<ref name=War2006/> People may also be switched to the long acting antidepressant [[fluoxetine]] which can then be gradually decreased.<ref name=Wil2015/>
<!-- Epidemiology and prognosis --> Approximately 20-50% of people who suddenly stop an antidepressant develop an antidepressant discontinuation syndrome.<ref name=War2006>{{cite journal |last1=Warner |first1=CH |last2=Bobo |first2=W |last3=Warner |first3=C |last4=Reid |first4=S |last5=Rachal |first5=J |title=Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome |journal=American Family Physician |date=1 August 2006 |volume=74 |issue=3 |pages=449–56 |pmid=16913164}}</ref><ref name=Gab2017>{{cite journal |last1=Gabriel |first1=M |last2=Sharma |first2=V |title=Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome |journal=Canadian Medical Association Journal |date=29 May 2017 |volume=189 |issue=21 |pages=E747 |doi=10.1503/cmaj.160991 |pmid=28554948|pmc=5449237 }}</ref><ref name=Dav2018 /> The condition is generally not serious.<ref name=War2006/> Though about half of people with symptoms describe them as severe.<ref name=Dav2018/> Some restart antidepressants due to the severity of the symptoms.<ref name=Dav2018/>
== Signs and symptoms == People with antidepressant discontinuation syndrome have been on an [[antidepressant]] for at least four weeks and have recently stopped taking the medication, whether abruptly, after a fast taper, or each time the medication is reduced on a slow taper.<ref name=War2006/> Commonly reported symptoms include flu-like symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headaches, sweating) and sleep disturbances (insomnia, nightmares, constant sleepiness). Sensory and movement disturbances have also been reported, including [[Balance (ability)|imbalance]], [[tremor]]s, [[vertigo]], dizziness, and electric-shock-like experiences in the brain, often described by people who have them as "brain zaps". Mood disturbances such as [[dysphoria]], anxiety, or agitation are also reported, as are cognitive disturbances such as confusion and [[Fight-or-flight response|hyperarousal]].
In cases associated with sudden discontinuation of [[Monoamine oxidase inhibitor|MAO inhibitors]], acute [[psychosis]] has been observed.<ref name=War2006/><ref name=Haddad2007>{{cite journal|last=Haddad |first=Peter M. |last2=Anderson |first2=Ian M. |date=October 2007 |title=Recognising and managing antidepressant discontinuation symptoms |journal=Advances in Psychiatric Treatment |volume=13 |issue=6 |pages=447–57 |doi=10.1192/apt.bp.105.001966 |doi-access=free |url=http://apt.rcpsych.org/content/13/6/447 }}</ref><ref name=Renoir2013>{{cite journal | author = Renoir T | year = 2013 | title = Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor antidepressant treatment discontinuation syndrome: a review of the clinical evidence and the possible mechanisms involved | url = | journal = Front Pharmacol | volume = 4 | issue = | page = 45 | doi = 10.3389/fphar.2013.00045 | pmid = 23596418 | pmc=3627130}}</ref> Over fifty symptoms have been reported.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Haddad PM, Dursun SM | year = 2008 | title = Neurological complications of psychiatric drugs: clinical features and management | url = | journal = Hum Psychopharmacol | volume = 23 | issue = Suppl 1| pages = 15–26 | doi = 10.1002/hup.918 |doi-access=free | pmid = 18098217 }}</ref>
Most cases of discontinuation syndrome may last between one and four weeks, are relatively mild, and resolve on their own; in more severe cases, symptoms can be severe or extended.<ref name=War2006/> [[Paroxetine]] and [[venlafaxine]] seem to be particularly difficult to discontinue, and [[Post-acute-withdrawal syndrome|prolonged withdrawal syndrome]] (post-acute-withdrawal syndrome, or PAWS) lasting over 18 months has been reported with paroxetine.<ref name="DrugSaf2001-Haddad" /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Tamam |first=L. |last2=Ozpoyraz |first2=N. |title=Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor Discontinuation Syndrome: A Review |journal=Advances in Therapy |date=January–February 2002 |volume=19 |issue=1 |pages=17–26 |doi=10.1007/BF02850015 |pmid=12008858}}</ref><ref name="2ndGenReview">{{cite report |last1=Gartlehner |first1=Gerald |last2=Hansen |first2=Richard A. |last3=Morgan |first3=Laura C. |last4=Thaler |first4=Kylie |last5=Lux |first5=Linda J. |last6=Noord |first6=Megan Van |last7=Mager |first7=Ursula |last8=Gaynes |first8=Bradley N. |last9=Thieda |first9=Patricia |last10=Strobelberger |first10=Michaela |last11=Lloyd |first11=Stacey |last12=Reichenpfader |first12=Ursula |last13=Lohr |first13=Kathleen N. |name-list-format=vanc |display-authors=3 |chapter=Results |chapter-url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK83447/ |title=Second-Generation Antidepressants in the Pharmacologic Treatment of Adult Depression: An Update of the 2007 Comparative Effectiveness Review |series=Comparative Effectiveness Reviews |number=46 |location=Rockville, MD |publisher=Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality |date=December 2011}}</ref>
A 2009 Advisory Committee to the FDA found that online anecdotal reports of discontinuation syndrome related to [[duloxetine]] (''Cymbalta'') included severe symptoms and exceeded prevalence of both paroxetine (''Paxil'') and venlafaxine (''Effexor'') reports by over 250% (although acknowledged this may have been influenced by duloxetine (''Cymbalta'') being a much newer drug).<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.fda.gov/downloads/AdvisoryCommittees/CommitteesMeetingMaterials/Drugs/PsychopharmacologicDrugsAdvisoryCommittee/UCM172866.pdf|title=Cymbalta (Duloxetine) Discontinuation Syndrome: Issues of Scope, Severity, Duration & Management|last=|first=|date=9 June 2009|website=|publisher=U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)|access-date=17 October 2016}}</ref> It also found that the safety information provided by the manufacturer not only neglected important information about managing discontinuation syndrome, but also explicitly advised against opening capsules, a practice required to gradually taper dosage.<ref name=":0" />
===Duration=== Symptoms usually resolve within two weeks but occasionally last up to one year.<ref name=Gab2017/>
They typically resolve within a day of restoring the medication.<ref>{{cite journal|first1=Peter M.|last1=Haddad|first2=Ian M.|last2=Anderson|title=Recognising and managing antidepressant discontinuation symptoms|url=http://apt.rcpsych.org/content/13/6/447|journal=Advances in Psychiatric Treatment|date=1 November 2007|issn=2056-4678|pages=447–457|volume=13|issue=6|doi=10.1192/apt.bp.105.001966}}</ref>
==Mechanism==
The underlying reason for its occurrence is unclear,<ref name=War2006/> though the syndrome appears similar to withdrawal from other psychotropic drugs such as [[Benzodiazepine withdrawal syndrome|benzodiazepines]].<ref name=TI2018/>
== Prevention and treatment ==
In some cases, discontinuation syndrome (withdrawal) may be prevented by taking medication as directed, and when discontinuing, doing so gradually, although symptoms may appear while tapering. When discontinuing an antidepressant with a short [[Biological half-life|half-life]], switching to a drug with a longer half-life (e.g. [[fluoxetine]] (''Prozac'') or [[citalopram]]) and then tapering, and eventually discontinuing, from that drug can decrease the severity of symptoms.<ref name=Haddad2007/>
Treatment is dependent on the severity of the discontinuation reaction and whether or not further antidepressant treatment is warranted. In cases where further antidepressant treatment is prescribed, then the only option suggested may be restarting the antidepressant. If antidepressants are no longer required, treatment depends on symptom severity. If symptoms of discontinuation are severe, or do not respond to symptom management, the antidepressant can be reinstated and then withdrawn more cautiously, or by switching to a drug with a longer half life, (such as ''Prozac''), and then tapering and discontinuing that drug.<ref name="DrugSaf2001-Haddad">{{cite journal|last=Haddad |first=Peter M. |title=Antidepressant discontinuation syndromes |journal=Drug Safety |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=183–97 |date=March 2001 |pmid=11347722 |doi=10.2165/00002018-200124030-00003 |subscription=yes}}</ref> In severe cases, hospitalization may be required.<ref name=War2006/>
=== Pregnancy and newborns === Antidepressants, including SSRIs, can cross the [[placenta]] and have the potential to affect the fetus and newborn, including an increased chance of [[miscarriage]], presenting a dilemma for pregnant women to decide whether to continue to take antidepressants at all, or if they do, considering if tapering and discontinuing during pregnancy could have a protective effect for the newborn.<ref name=Byatt>{{cite journal |vauthors=Byatt N, Deligiannidis KM, Freeman MP | date = Feb 2013 | title = Antidepressant use in pregnancy: a critical review focused on risks and controversies | journal = [[Acta Psychiatr Scand]] | volume = 127 | issue = 2| pages = 94–114 | doi = 10.1111/acps.12042 | pmid = 23240634 | pmc=4006272}}</ref>
Postnatal adaptation syndrome (PNAS) (originally called "neonatal behavioral syndrome", "poor neonatal adaptation syndrome", or "neonatal withdrawal syndrome") was first noticed in 1973 in newborns of mothers taking antidepressants; symptoms in the infant include [[irritability]], rapid breathing, [[hypothermia]], and [[blood sugar]] problems. The symptoms usually develop from birth to days after delivery and usually resolve within days or weeks of delivery.<ref name=Byatt/>
== Culture and history ==
Antidepressant discontinuation symptoms were first reported with [[imipramine]], the first [[tricyclic antidepressant]] (TCA), in the late 1950s, and each new class of antidepressants has brought reports of similar conditions, including [[monoamine oxidase inhibitor]]s (MAOIs), SSRIs, and SNRIs. As of 2001, at least 21 different antidepressants, covering all the major classes, were known to cause discontinuation syndromes.<ref name="DrugSaf2001-Haddad" /> The problem has been poorly studied, and most of the literature has been case reports or small [[Clinical trial|clinical studies]]; incidence is hard to determine and controversial.<ref name="DrugSaf2001-Haddad" />
With the explosion of use and interest in SSRIs in the late 1980s and early 1990s, focused especially on [[Prozac#Popular culture|Prozac]], interest grew as well in discontinuation syndromes.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/06/magazine/06antidepressant-t.html|work=New York Times |title=Self-Nonmedication |first=Bruce |last=Stutz |date=2007-05-06 |accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref> Some of the symptoms emerged from discussion boards where people with depression discussed their experiences with the disease and their medications; "brain zaps" or "brain shivers" was one symptom that emerged via these websites.<ref name="Christmas">{{cite journal|author=Christmas, M.B. |title='Brain shivers': from chat room to clinic |journal=Psychiatric Bulletin |year=2005 |volume=29 |pages=219–21 |url=http://pb.rcpsych.org/content/29/6/219 |doi=10.1192/pb.29.6.219 |issue=6}}</ref><ref name="Aronson">{{cite journal|author=Aronson, J. |title=Bottled lightning |journal=BMJ |date=8 October 2005 |volume=331 |page=824 |doi=10.1136/bmj.331.7520.824 |issue=7520 |pmc=1246084}}</ref>
Heightened media attention and continuing public concerns led to the formation of an expert group on the safety of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors in [[England]], to evaluate all the research available prior to 2004.<ref name="CSMExpert">{{cite web |url=http://www.mhra.gov.uk/home/groups/pl-p/documents/drugsafetymessage/con019472.pdf | title=Report of the CSM Expert Working Group on the Safety of Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor Antidepressants | publisher=Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency | date=December 2004 | accessdate=1 August 2014 | author=Expert Group on the Safety of Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) |editor-first=Ian V.D. |editor-last=Weller }}</ref>{{rp|iv}} The group determined that the incidence of discontinuation symptoms are between 5% and 49%, depending on the particular SSRI, the length of time on the medicine and abrupt versus gradual cessation.<ref name="CSMExpert"/>{{rp|126–136}}
With the lack of a definition based on consensus criteria for the syndrome, a panel met in [[Phoenix, Arizona]] in 1997 to form a draft definition,<ref>{{cite journal|author=Schatzberg, A.F. |author2=Haddad, P. |author3=Kaplan, E.M. |author4=Lejoyeux, M. |author5=Rosenbaum, J.F. |author6=Young, A.H. |author7=Zajecka, J. |title=Serotonin reuptake inhibitor discontinuation syndrome: a hypothetical definition. Discontinuation Consensus panel |journal=J Clin Psychiatry |volume=5u |issue=7 |pages=5–10 |year=1997 |pmid=9219487}}</ref> which other groups continued to refine.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Black, K. |author2=Shea, C. |author3=Dursun, S. |author4=Kutcher, S. |title=Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor discontinuation syndrome: proposed diagnostic criteria |journal=J Psychiatry Neurosci |volume=25 |issue=3 |pages=255–61 |year=2000 |pmid=10863885 |pmc=1407715}}</ref><ref name="who.int">{{cite report|author=World Health Organization |title=WHO Expert Committee on Drug Dependence – Thirty-third Report / WHO Technical Report Series 915 |publisher=World Health Organization |year=2003 |url=http://apps.who.int/medicinedocs/en/d/Js4896e/9.html}}</ref>
In the late 1990s, some investigators thought that the fact that symptoms emerged when antidepressants were discontinued might mean that antidepressants were causing [[addiction]], and some used the term "withdrawal syndrome" to describe the symptoms. While people taking antidepressants do not commonly exhibit drug seeking behavior, stopping antidepressants leads to similar symptoms as found in [[drug withdrawal]] from [[benzodiazapines]], and other psychotropic drugs.<ref>{{cite journal| author1=Nielsen, M. |author2=Hanse, E.H. |author3=Gøtzsche, P.C.|title=What is the difference between dependence and withdrawal reactions? A comparison of benzodiazepines and selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors|journal=Addiction |volume=105 |issue=5 |pages=900–8 |year=2012 |doi=10.1111/j.1360-0443.2011.03686.x |pmid=21992148 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| author1=Fava, G.A. |author2=Gatti, A |author3=Belaise, C. et al|title=Withdrawal Symptoms after Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor Discontinuation: A Systematic Review |journal= Psychother Psychosom |volume=84 |issue=2 |pages=72–81 |year=2015 |doi=10.1159/000370338 |pmid=25721705 }} </ref> As such, some researchers advocate the term withdrawal over discontinuation, to communicate the similar [[physiological dependence]] and negative outcomes.<ref name="TI2018" /> Due to pressure from pharmaceutical companies who make anti-depressants, the term "withdrawal syndrome" is no longer used by drug makers, and thus, most doctors, due to concerns that they may be compared to other drugs more commonly associated with withdrawal.<ref name=War2006/>
=== 2013 class action lawsuit ===
In 2013, a proposed class action lawsuit, ''Jennifer L Saavedra v. Eli Lilly and Company'',<ref>Justia. [http://dockets.justia.com/docket/california/cacdce/2:2012cv09366/546821 Jennifer L Saavedra v. Eli Lilly and Company]</ref> was brought against [[Eli Lilly and Company|Eli Lilly]] claiming that the [[Cymbalta]] label omitted important information about "brain zaps" and other symptoms upon cessation.<ref name="Law360">{{cite web |url=http://www.law360.com/articles/411089/lilly-fights-cymbalta-brain-zaps-suit-saying-it-warned-docs | title=Lilly Fights Cymbalta 'Brain Zaps' Suit, Saying It Warned Docs | publisher=Law360 | date=January 29, 2013 | accessdate=3 August 2014 | author=Overley, Jeff}}</ref> Eli Lilly moved for dismissal per the "[[learned intermediary]] doctrine" as the doctors prescribing the drug were warned of the potential problems and are an intermediary medical judgment between Lilly and patients; in December 2013 Lilly's motion to dismiss was denied.<ref>[[Rebecca Tushnet]] for Rebecca Tushnet's 43(B)log December 09, 2013 [http://tushnet.blogspot.com/2013/12/learned-intermediary-doctrine-doesnt.html Learned intermediary doctrine doesn't bar claim at pleading stage]</ref>
== Research == The mechanisms of antidepressant withdrawal syndrome have not yet been conclusively identified.<ref name=War2006/><ref name=Renoir2013/> The leading hypothesis is that after the antidepressant is discontinued, there is a temporary, but in some cases, long-lasting, deficiency in the brain of one or more essential [[neurotransmitters]] that regulate mood, such as [[serotonin]], [[dopamine]], [[norepinephrine]], and [[gamma-Aminobutyric acid|gamma-aminobutyric acid]], and since neurotransmitters are an interrelated system, dysregulation of one affects the others.<ref name=War2006/><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.4088/JCP.v65n0806 |author=Damsa, C. |title="Dopamine-dependent" side effects of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors: a clinical review |journal=J Clin Psychiatry |volume=65 |issue=8 |pages=1064–8 |date=August 2004 |pmid=15323590 |url=http://article.psychiatrist.com/?ContentType=START&ID=10001001 |author2=Bumb, A. |author3=Bianchi-Demicheli, F. |display-authors=3 |last4=Vidailhet |first4=Pierre |last5=Sterck |first5=Robert |last6=Andreoli |first6=Antonio |last7=Beyenburg |first7=Stefan}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Benzodiazepine withdrawal syndrome]]

{{other uses|Atos (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016 }} {{Infobox company | name = Atos SE | logo = Atos.svg | logo_size = 200px | logo_padding = 1em | type = ''[[Societas Europaea]]'' | traded_as = {{Unbulleted list|{{Euronext|ATO}}|[[CAC 40|CAC 40 Component]]}} | foundation = {{Start date and age|1988}} | location = [[Bezons]], France
| area_served = Worldwide | key_people = [[Thierry Breton]] {{Small|(Chairman & CEO)}} | industry = [[IT service management|IT services]], [[Information technology consulting|IT consulting]] | subsid = [[Syntel]] | services = Information Technology (Consulting, Systems Integration, Managed Services), [[business consulting]], [[outsourcing]] (such as [[Atos Healthcare|healthcare]]) | revenue = [[Euro|€]]12.69 billion (2017){{cite web|url=https://atos.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/atos-fy-2017-results-presentation.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180525133208/https://atos.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/atos-fy-2017-results-presentation.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 May 2018 |title=2017 Registration Document |accessdate=21 February 2018 |publisher=Atos SE |format=PDF }} | operating_income = €875 million (2017) | net_income = €665 million (2017) | assets = €13.5 billion (2017) | equity = €5.22 billion (2017) | num_employees = 120,000 (2018){{cite web|url=https://atos.net/en/about-us/company-profile|title=Company Profile|publisher=Atos SE|accessdate=2018-11-19}} | homepage = {{URL|http://atos.net/}} }} '''Atos''' is a European [[IT service management|IT services]] corporation with its headquarters in [[Bezons]], [[France]] and offices worldwide. It specialises in hi-tech transactional services, [[unified communications]], [[cloud service|cloud]], [[big data]] and [[cybersecurity]] services.{{cite news|title=Euronext Paris |url=https://europeanequities.nyx.com/en/products/equities/FR0000051732-XPAR/company-information |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130619014820/https://europeanequities.nyx.com/en/products/equities/FR0000051732-XPAR/company-information |archivedate=19 June 2013 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|title=CAC Mid 60 |url=https://indices.nyx.com/en/products/indices/QS0010989117-XPAR/quotes |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130619105607/https://indices.nyx.com/en/products/indices/QS0010989117-XPAR/quotes |archivedate=19 June 2013 |df=dmy }} Atos operates worldwide under the brands Atos, Atos Consulting, Atos Healthcare, Atos Worldgrid, Bull, Canopy, [[Unify Software and Solutions GmbH & Co. KG.|Unify]] and Worldline. ==History== [[File:AtosOrganigramme.png|thumb|right|400px|A diagram of the history of Atos acquisitions]] The company was formed in 1997 through a merger of two French IT companies; and combined with the Dutch-based company Origin B.V. in 2000 to become Atos Origin.{{cite web|url=http://atos.net/NR/rdonlyres/EBB49934-3EE4-4255-898B-720EEBB4D232/0/atos_annual_report_2011.pdf |title=Annual report 2011 |accessdate=23 February 2012 |publisher=Atos SE |format=PDF }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} It subsequently acquired [[KPMG]] Consulting in 2002 and [[SchlumbergerSema]] in 2004. In 2010 Atos Origin announced the buyout of [[Siemens IT Solutions and Services]] and finalized the acquisition in July 2011. Afterwards, the company name reverted to Atos.{{cite news|title=Atos acquires Siemens IT Solutions and Services|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-07-01/news/29726117_1_atos-origin-siemens-ag-share-capital|accessdate=5 August 2012|newspaper=The Economic Times|date=1 July 2012}}{{cite news|title=Atos Origin acquires Siemens division for €850m|url=http://www.computerweekly.com/news/1280094628/Atos-Origin-acquires-Siemens-division-for-850m|accessdate=27 May 2013|newspaper=Computer Weekly|date=15 December 2010}} In April 2018, Atos partnered with Google Cloud to help offer secure artificial intelligence solutions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-atos-google-cloud/atos-partners-with-google-cloud-as-new-eu-data-law-looms-idUSKBN1HV2MV|title=Atos partners with Google Cloud as new EU data law looms|last=Jacob|first=Manon|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-05-23|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cxotoday.com/story/atos-google-partner-to-boost-enterprise-collaboration/|title=Atos, Google Partner To Boost Enterprise Collaboration - CXOtoday.com|website=www.cxotoday.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-23}} [[File:AtosOrigin.svg|thumb|right|Logo of Atos Origin used prior to July 2011]] === Background: a series of mergers (1997–2011) === In 1996, Origin B.V. was created after a merger of the Dutch company BSO and the Philips C&P (Communications & Processing) division, while a year later in 1997, Atos was created following a merger of the French companies Axime and Sligos.{{cite web|title=Axime, Sligos merger named Atos Origin|url=http://www.telecompaper.com/news/axime-sligos-merger-named-atos|publisher=Telecompaper|date=29 May 1997|accessdate=29 April 2016}} In 2001, Atos Origin sold its Nordic operations to WM-data. In 2002, it made a major acquisition by buying [[KPMG Consulting]] in the United Kingdom and in the Netherlands. Then in 2004, it acquired [[Sema Group|SchlumbergerSema]], the IT service division of [[Schlumberger]] and took over the infrastructure division of ITELLIUM, a subsidiary of [[KarstadtQuelle]].{{cite web|title=Atos Origin acquires German IT unit under outsourcing deal|url=http://www.consultant-news.com/article_display.aspx?p=adp&id=1738|website=ConsultantNews.com|accessdate=8 September 2004}} At the same time (2004), the company created a new subsidiary, Atos Worldline, and the renaming of its consulting activities as Atos Consulting. Also in 2004, Atos Origin Australia, originating from [[Philips]], was sold to Fujitsu. In 2005, Atos Origin sold its activities in the Nordic region, which had become part of the company with the acquisition of Sema Group, to [[WM-data]] while in 2006, Atos Origin sold its operations in the Middle East to local management.{{cite news|title=Atos Origin sells Nordic IT services ops to WM-data for 145 mln eur cash |url=https://www.forbes.com/feeds/afx/2005/05/23/afx2046385.html |accessdate=2 September 2010 |newspaper=[[Forbes]] |date=23 May 2005 |agency=[[AFX News]] }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} In October 2007, Philippe Germond replaced longtime CEO Bernard Bourigeaud. Two shareholders, the [[hedge fund]]s Centaurus Capital and Pardus Capital, tried to gain control over the company via the supervisory board.{{cite news|last=Chassany|first=Anne-Sylvaine|title=Atos Origin Board Fires Chief Germond, Hires Breton|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aOpHCL50TOTA|accessdate=2 September 2010|date=17 November 2008|agency=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]}} In November 2008, the boardroom battle came to an end when [[Thierry Breton]] replaced Philippe Germond as chairman and CEO. In August 2010 Atos Origin acquired Indian payment company Venture Infotek. === Doubling size with acquisition of Siemens IT (2011) === In December 2010 Atos Origin agreed to acquire the IT Solutions and Services subsidiary of [[Siemens]] for €850 million.{{cite news|title=Atos Origin To Buy Siemens AG's IT Unit In EUR850M Deal|url=http://www.advfn.com/news_UPDATE-Atos-Origin-To-Buy-Siemens-AGs-IT-Unit-In-EUR850-Million-Deal_45655050.html|accessdate=2 July 2011|date=14 December 2010|agency=[[Dow Jones Newswires]]}} As part of the transaction, Siemens agreed to take a 15% stake in the enlarged Atos, to be held for a minimum of five years. The company dropped the "Origin" suffix of its name in July 2011 after completing its acquisition of the Siemens unit.{{cite news|title=Atos Origin changes name amid acquisition|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/atos-origin-changes-name-amid-acquisition-2011-07-01|accessdate=2 July 2011|date=1 July 2011|agency=[[MarketWatch]]}} [[File:Atos Headquarters.JPG|left|thumb|Atos headquarters in Bezons (France)]] In November 2011 Atos and software services provider Ufida International Holdings formed the joint venture Yunano. The two companies invested €5.7 million. Atos has 70 percent and UFIDA has 30 percent. The joint venture has its HQ in [[Bezons]], France, a suburb of Paris.{{cite web|url=http://www.telecompaper.com/news/atos-ufida-form-yunano-joint-venture-in-emea-china|title=Atos, Ufida form Yunano joint venture in EMEA, China|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016}} In 2012 Atos announced the creation of a new company called Canopy.{{cite web | url=http://www.cio.com/article/700240/EMC_and_VMware_Team_with_Atos_to_Create_European_Cloud_Company_Canopy | title= CIO.com | accessdate=15 February 2012 }} The CEO is Philippe Llorens.{{cite web |url=https://canopy-cloud.com/about |title=About Canopy |accessdate=18 August 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.vmware.com/company/news/vmworld-cloud-ops-supporting-partner-quotes-082712.html |title=Industry Support for the Cloud Operations Forum |accessdate=21 December 2012}} In 2011 Atos introduced a Zero Email initiative,{{cite news|title=The IT Boss Who Shuns Email|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204452104577060103165399154|work=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=28 November 2011|first1=Max|last1=Colchester|first2=Geraldine|last2=Amiel|date=28 November 2011}} banning email as a form of internal communications, except for use with customers and prospects.{{cite news|title=Zero Email Has Zero Chance, But How About An Email Diet?|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/larrymagid/2011/12/02/zero-email-has-zero-chance-but-how-about-an-email-diet/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=2 December 2011|first=Larry|last=Magid}} As part of the initiative, Atos acquired the French software company blueKiwi in early 2012, rolling out their ZEN social networking software across its organisation.{{cite web|title=Atos drives for zero email with blueKiwi ZEN roll out |url=http://www.computerworlduk.com/news/applications/3409636/atos-drives-for-zero-email-with-bluekiwi-zen-roll-out/|publisher=Computer World UK|accessdate=7 November 2012}} === Acquisition of information technology pioneer Bull (2014) === In August 2014 Atos announced that it had acquired a controlling stake in [[Groupe Bull|Bull SA]] through a tender offer launched in May. {{cite web |url = http://www.pcworld.com/article/2463600/atos-succeeds-in-bid-to-buy-bull-will-boost-security-and-cloud-offerings.html |title = Atos succeeds in bid to buy Bull |accessdate = 11 October 2014 }} Atos announced plans in October 2014 to buy out or squeeze out the remaining share and bondholders of Bull. {{cite web |url = http://www.telecompaper.com/news/atos-to-launch-buyout-of-last-5-of-bull-shares-bonds--10405950 |title = Atos to launch buyout of last 5% of Bull shares, bonds |accessdate = 11 October 2014 }} === North American footprint with Xerox ITO acquisition (2015) === On 19 December 2014 Atos announced the acquisition of [[Xerox]]'s IT Outsourcing business for {{currency|1.05 billion}}, tripling the size of the North American business.{{cite news | author=Patnaik, Subrat | author2=Baker, Liana B. | agency=Reuters | title=Xerox to sell IT outsourcing arm to France's Atos for $1.05 billion | date=18 December 2014 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/19/us-xerox-atos-deals-idUSKBN0JW2U920141219 }} The unit generated {{currency|376 million}} in Q3 2014, contains 9,800 employees and operates in 45 countries. The transaction closed on 30 June 2015.{{cite web|url=http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2015/pr-2015_06_30_03.html|title="Atos completes the acquisition of Xerox ITO " - Atos|date=30 June 2015|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016}} === Acquisition of U.S.-based multinational SYNTEL,Inc(2018) === On July 22, 2018 A powerful combination for Atos by acquiring a highly complementary portfolio, customer base and geographic footprint with 23,000 new joiners highly skilled in digital services.Atos and Syntel have entered into a definitive merger agreement under which Atos will acquire Syntel for cash consideration of c. $ 3.4 billion i.e. $ 41.0 per share, representing c. 14% premium over the last 30 trading days volume weighted average share price of Syntel. it brings a powerful suite of digital and proprietary solutions recognized by top analysts as being among the most advanced: cloud, social media, mobile, analytics, IoT, and automation at c. 40% of Syntel’s revenue .Syntel will significantly strengthen the Group’s Business & Platform Solutions Division worldwide with best-in-class delivery platform generating among the highest margins of the industry .This transaction expands Atos’s capabilities in North America to provide end-to-end services to US customers. It also strongly reinforces its Banking, Finance & Insurance verticals == Services and Activities == === Global services === Atos activities are organized in four divisions:{{cite web|url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2016/11/08/887601/0/en/ATOS-Atos-presents-its-new-3-year-plan-2019-Ambition.html|title=Atos presents its new 3-year plan: 2019 Ambition|website=Nasdaq GlobeNewswire|accessdate=20 April 2017}} * ''Infrastructure & Data Management'': [[Datacenter]] management, service desk and [[unified communications]]; * ''Business Applications & Platform Solutions'': [[consulting]] & [[systems integration]]; * ''[[Big Data]] & Cybersecurity'': production of [[high-performance computers]] & [[server (computing)|server]]s and [[cybersecurity]]; * Worldline : [[e-commerce]] payment services and POS terminal solutions. === Activities === Positioned as a vendor of holistic digital transformation,{{cite web|last1=Bakalova|first1=Elitsa|title=Positioning as a vendor of holistic digital transformation drove growth for Atos in 2016|url=http://tbri.com/analyst-perspectives/analyst-commentary/pgView.cfm?commentary=3037|website=TBR - Technology Business Research|accessdate=20 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171208175115/http://tbri.com/analyst-perspectives/analyst-commentary/pgView.cfm?commentary=3037|archive-date=8 December 2017|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Atos builds on four pillars within its ''Digital Transformation Factory'':{{cite web|title=Atos builds on digital transformation demand|url=http://www.iteuropa.com/?q=atos-builds-digital-transformation-demand|website=IT Europa|accessdate=20 April 2017}} ==== Cloud ==== * ''[[Cloud_computing]]'': implementation and management of private and [[hybrid cloud]]s. ==== Digital Workplace ==== * ''Digital Workplace'': digital [[Service desk (ITSM)|end-user support]] and unified communications services and products derived from the [[Unify GmbH & Co. KG|Unify]] acquisition. In September 2017, Atos has been recognized by [[Everest Group]] as a global leader - the only European one - for workplace services, consisting of mobility and security services in [[As a service|as-a-service]] mode, [[service desk]] and [[unified communications]]{{cite web|title=Atos recognized as a Global Leader in Workplace Services by Everest Group|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/press-release/atos-recognized-as-a-global-leader-in-workplace-services-by-everest-group-20170906-00116|website=Nasdaq|publisher=Nasdaq|accessdate=7 September 2017}}. ==== SAP HANA ==== * ''[[SAP HANA]]'': implementation and management of integrated [[enterprise resource planning]] software SAP HANA. ==== Big Data Analytics ==== * ''Atos Codex'': end-to-end analytics suite including [[business analytics]] and [[predictive analytics]] solutions. === Geographies === ==== North America ==== After the Xerox ITO acquisition, North America has become Atos's largest business unit. ==== United Kingdom ==== According to a [[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)|National Audit Office]] report on the government's four biggest suppliers, Atos earned £700 million in revenue from the public sector in the UK in 2012; of £7.2 billion sales worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/5abc8d36-9a28-11e3-8232-00144feab7de.html|title=Subscribe to read|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016}} Atos holds £3 billion worth of UK government contracts providing services to a wide range of organizations including [[NHS Scotland]], [[Home Office]],[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2012/06/01/border_agency_it_crash_atos/ "The Great Border Agency IT crash. Just who was responsible?"] by Anna Leach. 1 June 2012 [[Welsh Government]],{{cite news|last=du Preez|first=Derek|title=Welsh government extends Atos deal for five years|url=http://www.computerworlduk.com/news/public-sector/3366102/welsh-government-extends-atos-deal-for-five-years/?intcmp=in_article;related|accessdate=28 May 2013|date=25 June 2012|newspaper=[[Computer World]]}} the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]],{{cite web|title=Atos team wins major new contract with the UK Ministry of Defence|url=http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2013/pr-2013_04_19_01.html|work=Atos Press Release|accessdate=28 May 2013|date=19 April 2013}} [[Transport for Greater Manchester]],{{cite web|url=http://manchestermule.com/article/atos-selected-to-run-manchester-oyster-card-scheme|title=» Atos selected to run Manchester ‘Oyster Card’ scheme - MULE|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016}} the [[BBC]]{{cite web|title=BBC starts search for suppliers to replace £2 billion Atos outsourcing deal|url=http://www.computerweekly.com/news/2240214384/BBC-starts-search-for-suppliers-to-replace-2bn-Atos-outsourcing-deal|accessdate=14 February 2014|date=14 February 2014}} and a multimillion outsourcing contract to [[NS&I]].[http://www.nsandi.com/media-centre-nsi-awards-outsourcing-contract-atos NS&I awards outsourcing contract to Atos] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130706201646/http://www.nsandi.com/media-centre-nsi-awards-outsourcing-contract-atos |date=6 July 2013 }} In the United Kingdom, from 1998 - 2015 the company was at the centre of a controversy over the management of [[Atos Healthcare|contracts by their healthcare division]] of the [[Work Capability Assessment]] for the [[Department for Work and Pensions]] (DWP).[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22546036 "Disability benefit assessments 'unfair', says ex-worker"]. ==== Asia-Pacific ==== In January 2017, Atos secured a five-year contract as key IT partner of the [[Western Australia]]n state government. Extendable for an additional five years, the deal (up to $2.39 billion) will be allocated with two other ICT suppliers.{{cite web|title=Atos secures a five-year contract as key it partner of the Western Australian state government|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSFWN1FD0U9|website=Reuters|accessdate=2017-04-17}} == Controversy == === Atos Healthcare === {{Main article|Work Capability Assessment}}In the United Kingdom, from 1998 - 2015 Atos Healthcare was at the centre of a controversy over the management of [[Atos Healthcare|contracts by their healthcare division]] of the [[Work Capability Assessment]] for the [[Department for Work and Pensions]] (DWP). In August 2015, statistics from the Department of Work and Pensions revealed that 2,380 people had died between 2011 - 2014 soon after being found fit for work through disability benefit assessments.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/aug/27/thousands-died-after-fit-for-work-assessment-dwp-figures|title=Thousands have died after being found fit for work, DWP figures show|first=Patrick Butler Social policy|last=editor|date=27 August 2015|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016|via=The Guardian}} In 2014, "the DWP negotiated an early exit from the existing WCA contract with the private firm, Atos, after raising concerns about the quality of its work".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-26287199|title=Atos seeks early exit from fit-to-work tests contract|date=21 February 2014|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/jul/23/disability-fitness-tests-flawed|title=Disabled people's 'fit for work' assessments should be scrapped – MPs|first=Patrick|last=Butler|date=22 July 2014|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016|via=The Guardian}} However, Atos still (as of October 2016) undertakes work for the DWP in assessing [[Personal Independence Payment]] applications.[https://web.archive.org/web/20161005193723/http://www.atoshealthcare.com/pip/] The Press Association revealed in 2017 that Atos, used by the DWP to make its decisions, are set to be paid more than £700m for their five-year contracts against an original estimate of £512m.[The Independent] When Atos took over administering PIP's estimates of how fast claims could be processed were over-optimistic as were estimates of how easily claimants could get to assessment centres. This led to delays in assessments, distress to claimants and unexpectedly high costs. Atos was accused of misleading the government.[https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/mar/20/atos-accused-misleading-government-process-claims-sick-disabled Atos accused of misleading government over how quickly it could process claims] ''[[The Guardian]]'' Atos developed a computer system that would extract data from GP's computers Nationwide. Costs rose from £14 million to £40 million and it was felt Atos had taken insufficient care how it spent taxpayers' money.[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2016/03/07/government_reviews_atos_contracts/ UK.gov will scrutinise all its Atos contracts following IT cock-up] Atos lost the contract for fitness to work tests, Richard Hawkes of [[Scope (charity)|Scope]] said, "I doubt there's a single disabled person who'll be sorry to hear that Atos will no longer be running the fit-for-work tests." Hawkes claimed the "fundamentally flawed" test should be "more than an exercise in getting people off benefits. It should make sure disabled people get the specialist, tailored and flexible support they need to find and keep a job." [[Mark Serwotka]] of [[Public and Commercial Services Union]] described the assessments as "designed to harass vulnerable people and take their benefits away rather than provide support and guidance. Doctors, MPs and disabled people all believe the tests should be scrapped so, instead of replacing the failed Atos with another profit-hungry provider, the government should bring the work in-house and invest in it properly."[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-26766345 Fit-to-work tests: Atos contract to end] ''[[BBC]]'' [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrat]] leader, [[Tim Farron]] questioned how Atos and [[Capita]] could have been paid over £500m from tax payers money for assessing fitness to work as 61% who appealed won their appeals. Farron stated, “This adds to the suspicion that these companies are just driven by a profit motive, and the incentive is to get the assessments done, but not necessarily to get the assessments right. They are the ugly face of business.”[https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/dec/27/private-firms-500m-governments-fit-to-work-scheme Private firms earn £500m from government's fit-to-work scheme] ''[[The Guardian]]'' In 2014, Atos Healthcare rebranded its occupational health business to become OH Assist. The Atos Healthcare brand was reserved for use for the PIP contract. Atos sold its OH Assist business to CBPE Capital in 2015. {{Cite web|url=https://www.latentexistence.me.uk/the-atos-name-is-toxic-atos-spins-off-oh-assist/|title=The Atos name is toxic - Atos spins off OH Assist|last=|first=|date=25 February 2014|website=|publisher=|access-date=19 January 2017}} === Corporation tax === It was disclosed in November 2013 through the [[National Audit Office (United Kingdom)|National Audit Office]] that Atos had paid no corporation tax at all in the UK in 2012.{{cite news|author=Christopher Hope|title=Atos, G4S paid no corporation tax last year despite carrying out £2billion of taxpayer-funded work|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/10442231/Atos-G4S-paid-no-corporation-tax-last-year-despite-carrying-out-2billion-of-taxpayer-funded-work.html|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=12 November 2013|location=London}} The total value of contracts that had been awarded to Atos by June 2013 was approximately £1.6 billion.{{cite web|title=Cost of Atos and Capita|url=http://www.disabilityrightsuk.org/news/2013/june/cost-atos-and-capita|publisher=Disability Rights UK|date=12 June 2013}} ==Sponsorship== ===Olympic/Paralympic Games=== Atos has been the official IT Partner for the [[Olympic Games]] since 2001 and is expected to continue until at least 2020.{{cite news| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/02/08/us-olympics-atos-idUKBREA170M420140208 | work=Reuters | title=IOC extends sponsor deal with Atos to 2020 | date=8 February 2014}} Atos, through the SchlumbergerSema's acquisition, was involved in previous Games during the 1990s, starting with the [[1992 Summer Olympics|Barcelona Olympic Games]] in 1992. Atos has been one of 11 major sponsors for the Olympic Games since 2001.{{cite news|title=FACTBOX-Olympics-Who are the global sponsors?|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/17/oly-sponsors-top-adv-idUSL6E8IHH0020120717|accessdate=5 August 2012|agency=Reuters|date=17 July 2012|first=Keith|last=Weir}} In 2011, some UK-based disability campaign groups called for a boycott of the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] due to Atos' sponsorship of the games and Atos Healthcare's UK contract to perform Work Capability Assessments on behalf of the Department of Work and Pensions (DWP){{cite news|last=Razzall|first=Katie|title=Campaigners threaten Paralympics boycott|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/campaigners-threaten-paralympics-boycott|accessdate=27 October 2011|date=30 September 2011|work=[[Channel 4 News]]}} During the first week of the [[Paralympics]] in the summer of 2012, activists and disabled people targeted Atos in a series of nationwide protests.{{cite news|last=McCarthy|first=James|title=Disabled People Against Cuts stage demo against Paralympics sponsor|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/cardiffonline/cardiff-news/2012/08/30/disabled-people-against-cuts-stage-demo-against-paralympics-sponsor-91466-31727698/|accessdate=4 September 2012|newspaper=Wales Online|date=30 August 2012}} This culminated on Friday 31 August with a demonstration outside Atos headquarters in London,[https://www.theguardian.com/society/2012/aug/31/atos-protest-paralympics-sponsor "Atos protesters clash with police in 'day of action' against Paralympics sponsor"] 31 August 2012. ''The Guardian'' which ended in a confrontation with the police.{{cite news|title=Atos protest: Disability rights groups target firm|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-19437785|accessdate=2 September 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=31 August 2012}} Through the [[International Olympic Committee]]'s TOP (The Olympic Partner) programme, Atos has sponsored athletes from all over the globe in order to support their Olympic ambitions, including [[Danny Crates]], the 2004 Paralympic Champion in the 800m.{{cite web|url=http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2006/pr-2006_03_13_01.html|title="Atos Origin Announces Sponsorship of Danny Crates - 800m Paralympic Champion" - Atos|date=13 March 2006|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023062333/http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2006/pr-2006_03_13_01.html|archive-date=23 October 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2007/pr-2007_09_27_01.html|title="Atos Origin supports high-jumper athlete Tia Hellebaut" - Atos|date=27 September 2007|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140211124522/http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2007/pr-2007_09_27_01.html|archive-date=11 February 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2004/pr-2004_06_15_01.html|title="Atos Origin announces sponsorship of world's number one pentathlete" - Atos|date=15 June 2004|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140211124517/http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2004/pr-2004_06_15_01.html|archive-date=11 February 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2006/pr-2006_06_19_02.html|title="Atos Origin Sponsors U.S. Olympian, and International Triathlon Union World Cup Champion Hunter Kemper" - Atos|date=19 June 2006|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160429073255/http://atos.net/en-us/home/we-are/news/press-release/2006/pr-2006_06_19_02.html|archive-date=29 April 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ===2014 Commonwealth Games=== Atos was named as an official supporter of the [[2014 Commonwealth Games]] in [[Glasgow]].{{cite web|url=http://www.glasgow2014.com/press-releases/international-it-company-atos-become-official-supporter-glasgow-2014|title=International IT company Atos become Official Supporter of Glasgow 2014|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2016}} On 26 June 2013, "Glasgow Against Atos" occupied one of the Commonwealth Games venues in protest against Atos sponsorship.[http://gamesmonitor2014.org/2013/06/27/chris-hoy-velodrome-occupied/ Chris Hoy Velodrome Occupied] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225195015/http://gamesmonitor2014.org/2013/06/27/chris-hoy-velodrome-occupied/ |date=25 February 2014 }} Games Monitor 2014 ===2015 Southeast Asian Games=== Atos was the official sponsor of [[2015 Southeast Asian Games]] in [[Singapore]].[https://www.seagames2015.com/get-involved/sponsors/official-sponsors Official Sponsors 2015 South East Asian Games] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702104830/https://www.seagames2015.com/get-involved/sponsors/official-sponsors |date=2 July 2015 }} === 2018 European Championships === In February 2017 Atos has been appointed as the first official sponsor of the [[Glasgow]] 2018 European Championships. The company has been awarded a £2.5 million contract for timing, scoring and results.{{cite web|title=£10m for companies involved in Glasgow 2018 European Championship|url=http://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/14946104.__10m_for_companies_involved_in_Glasgow_2018_European_Championship/|website=Evening Times|accessdate=20 February 2017}} ==See also== {{Portal|Companies}} *[[List of IT consulting firms]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Atos SE}} *{{Official website|http://atos.net}} {{Siemens}} {{Consulting}} {{Major information technology consulting and outsourcing companies}} [[Category:Information technology companies of France]] [[Category:International information technology consulting firms]] [[Category:Business services companies established in 2000]] [[Category:Companies based in Paris]] [[Category:Disability in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Protests in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:21st-century controversies]] [[Category:Medical technology companies of France]] [[Category:Societates Europaeae]] [[Category:Outsourcing companies]]

Soluble in water | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160811095753/http://www.chemspider.com/Chemical-Structure.62571.html | archivedate=11 August 2016 }} }} '''β-Hydroxy β-methylbutyric acid'''{{#tag:ref|Synonyms and alternate spellings include: '''{{nowrap|''beta''-hydroxy}} {{nowrap|''beta''-methylbutyric}} acid''', '''{{nowrap|3-hydroxy-3-methylbutanoic}} acid''' ([[International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry|IUPAC]] name), '''{{nowrap|3-hydroxyisovaleric}} acid''', and '''{{nowrap|''beta''-hydroxyisovaleric}} acid'''.{{cite encyclopedia | title = beta-Hydroxyisovaleric acid | url = https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/69362 | work = PubChem Compound | publisher = United States National Library of Medicine – National Center for Biotechnology Information | accessdate = 6 February 2018 | date = 3 February 2018 | quote = Chemical Names: Beta-Hydroxyisovaleric acid; 3-Hydroxy-3-methylbutanoic acid; ... 3-Hydroxyisovaleric acid; 3-Hydroxy-3-methylbutyric acid | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180206190322/https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/69362 | archivedate = 6 February 2018}}| group = "note" }} ('''HMB'''), otherwise known as its [[conjugate base]], '''{{nowrap|β-hydroxy β-methylbutyrate}}''', is a [[natural product|naturally produced]] substance in humans that is used as a [[dietary supplement]] and as an ingredient in certain [[medical food]]s that are intended to promote [[wound healing]] and provide nutritional support for people with [[muscle atrophy|muscle wasting]] due to [[cancer]] or [[HIV/AIDS]].{{#tag:ref||group="sources"}} In healthy adults, supplementation with HMB has been shown to increase exercise-induced gains in muscle size, [[muscle strength]], and [[lean body mass]], reduce [[skeletal muscle]] damage from exercise, improve aerobic exercise performance, and expedite recovery from exercise. [[Literature review|Medical reviews]] and [[Meta-analysis|meta-analyses]] indicate that HMB supplementation also helps to preserve or increase lean body mass and muscle strength in individuals experiencing [[sarcopenia|age-related muscle loss]]. HMB produces these effects in part by stimulating the [[protein synthesis|production of proteins]] and inhibiting the [[protein breakdown|breakdown of proteins]] in muscle tissue. No [[adverse effect]]s from long-term use as a dietary supplement in adults have been found. HMB is a [[metabolite]] of [[leucine|{{nowrap|{{smallcaps all|L}}-leucine}}]] and is produced in the body through oxidation of the [[ketoacid]] of {{nowrap|{{smallcaps all|L}}-leucine}} ([[α-ketoisocaproic acid]]). Since only a small fraction of {{nowrap|{{smallcaps all|L}}-leucine}} is metabolized into HMB, [[pharmacologically active]] concentrations of the compound in [[blood plasma]] and muscle can only be achieved by supplementing HMB directly. A healthy adult produces approximately 0.3 grams of HMB per day, while supplemental HMB is usually taken in doses of {{nowrap|3–6}} grams per day. HMB is sold as a dietary supplement at a cost of about {{nowrap|{{currency|30|USD}}–50}} per month when taking 3 grams per day. HMB is also contained in several nutritional products, including certain formulations of [[Ensure]], [[Juven]], and [[Myoplex]]. HMB is also present in insignificant quantities in certain foods, such as [[alfalfa]], [[asparagus]], [[avocado]]s, [[cauliflower]], [[grapefruit]], and [[catfish]]. The effects of HMB on human skeletal muscle were first discovered by Steven L. Nissen at [[Iowa State University]] in the {{nowrap|mid-1990s}}. {{As of|2018|post=,}} HMB has not been banned by the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]], [[World Anti-Doping Agency]], or any other prominent national or international athletic organization. In 2006, only about 2% of college [[student athlete]]s in the United States used HMB as a dietary supplement. As of 2017, HMB has found widespread use as an [[ergogenic supplement]] among young athletes. ==Uses== ===Available forms=== HMB is sold as an [[over-the-counter]] [[dietary supplement]] in the [[free acid]] form, ''β-hydroxy β-methylbutyric acid'' (HMB-FA), and as a [[monohydrate]]d calcium [[salt (chemistry)|salt]] of the [[conjugate base]], ''calcium {{nowrap|β-hydroxy β-methylbutyrate}} monohydrate'' (HMB-Ca, CaHMB).{{cite journal | vauthors = Momaya A, Fawal M, Estes R | title = Performance-enhancing substances in sports: a review of the literature | journal = Sports Medicine | volume = 45 | issue = 4 | pages = 517–531 | date = April 2015 | pmid = 25663250 | doi = 10.1007/s40279-015-0308-9 | quote = Currently, HMB is available as an over-the-counter supplement. The drug is not tested for nor banned by any sporting organization. ... Wilson et al. [91] demonstrated that when non-resistance trained males received HMB pre-exercise, the rise of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels reduced, and HMB tended to decrease soreness. Knitter et al. [92] showed a decrease in LDH and creatine phosphokinase (CPK), a byproduct of muscle breakdown, by HMB after a prolonged run. ... The utility of HMB does seem to be affected by timing of intake prior to workouts and dosage [97]. Further, chronic consumption of HMB appears safe [97]. ... No serious adverse effects from HMB consumption have been reported. }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Fuller JC, Sharp RL, Angus HF, Khoo PY, Rathmacher JA | title = Comparison of availability and plasma clearance rates of β-hydroxy-β-methylbutyrate delivery in the free acid and calcium salt forms | journal = The British Journal of Nutrition | volume = 114 | issue = 9 | pages = 1403–1409 | date = November 2015 | pmid = 26373270 | doi = 10.1017/S0007114515003050 | department = primary source | quote = Recently, the free acid form of HMB (HMB-FA) has become commercially available in capsule form (gelcap). The current study was conducted to compare the bioavailability of HMB using the two commercially available capsule forms of HMB-FA and Ca-HMB. ... In conclusion, HMB-FA in capsule form improves clearance rate and availability of HMB compared with Ca-HMB in capsule form. }} Since only a small fraction of HMB's metabolic precursor, {{nowrap|{{smallcaps all|L}}-leucine}}, is metabolized into HMB, pharmacologically active concentrations of the compound in [[blood plasma]] and muscle can only be achieved by supplementing HMB directly.{{cite journal | vauthors = Landi F, Calvani R, Tosato M, Martone AM, Ortolani E, Savera G, D'Angelo E, Sisto A, Marzetti E | title = Protein Intake and Muscle Health in Old Age: From Biological Plausibility to Clinical Evidence | journal = Nutrients | volume = 8 | issue = 5 | pages = 295 | date = May 2016 | pmid = 27187465 | pmc = 4882708 | doi = 10.3390/nu8050295 | quote = HMB is an active leucine metabolite which activates the mTOR signaling pathway in muscle. Following its absorption, dietary leucine is converted into α-ketoisocaproate (KIC), which is further metabolized into either isovaleryl-CoA or HMB. Under normal conditions, the majority of KIC is converted into isovaleryl-CoA, while only approximately 5% of leucine is metabolized to HMB. This implies that, in order to reach pharmacological levels of HMB, this compound needs to be administered directly, rather than via increasing leucine dosage. ... HMB exerts its effects through protective, anticatabolic mechanisms and directly influences protein synthesis. HMB has also been shown to stabilize the muscle cell membrane, to modulate protein degradation and to up-regulate protein synthesis [68]. }} A healthy adult produces approximately 0.3 grams per day, while supplemental HMB is usually taken in doses of {{nowrap|3–6}} grams per day.{{cite journal | vauthors = Molfino A, Gioia G, Rossi Fanelli F, Muscaritoli M | title = Beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate supplementation in health and disease: a systematic review of randomized trials | journal = Amino Acids | volume = 45 | issue = 6 | pages = 1273–1292 | date = December 2013 | pmid = 24057808 | doi = 10.1007/s00726-013-1592-z | quote = Normally, an individual metabolizes 60 g of L-LEU to obtain 3 g of HMB but a 70 kg person produces 0.2–0.4 g of HMB per day, depending on the dose of LEU in the diet (Van Koevering and Nissen 1992). ... The usual dose of 3 g/day may be routinely recommended to maintain or improve muscle mass and function in health and disease. The safety profile of HMB is unequivocal. ... These results show that HMB/ARG/GLN can be safely used to treat AIDS- and cancer-related muscle wasting }} HMB is sold at a cost of about {{nowrap|{{currency|30|USD}}–50}} per month when taken in doses of 3 grams per day. HMB is also contained in several nutritional products and medical foods marketed by [[Abbott Laboratories]] (e.g., certain formulations of [[Ensure]], [[Juven]], and [[Myoplex]]),{{cite web|vauthors=Linn J|title=Proteins in Human Health and Performance|url=http://www.fshn.hs.iastate.edu/proteins-in-human-health-and-performance/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160827191643/http://www.fshn.hs.iastate.edu/proteins-in-human-health-and-performance/|archive-date=27 August 2016|publisher=Iowa State University|accessdate=31 July 2016|date=13 May 2013|quote=Dr. Nissen and his collaborator Dr. Naji N. Abumrad, Professor and Chair, Department of Surgery, Vanderbilt University, discovered beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate (HMB) and its beneficial effects on human health and performance. HMB is currently marketed nationally by Abbott Laboratories as Revigor™, which is a component of Ensure® Muscle Health, and Juven®, which is a nutritional beverage that is clinically shown to promote healing after injury or surgery.|deadurl=yes}} and is present in insignificant quantities in certain foods, such as [[alfalfa]], [[asparagus]], [[avocado]]s, [[cauliflower]], [[grapefruit]], and [[catfish]].{{cite journal | vauthors = Wilson GJ, Wilson JM, Manninen AH | title = Effects of beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate (HMB) on exercise performance and body composition across varying levels of age, sex, and training experience: A review | journal = Nutrition & Metabolism | volume = 5 | issue = | pages = 1 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 18173841 | pmc = 2245953 | doi = 10.1186/1743-7075-5-1 }} ===Medical=== Supplemental HMB has been used in [[clinical trial]]s as a treatment for preserving lean body mass in muscle wasting conditions, particularly [[sarcopenia]], and has been studied in clinical trials as an [[adjunct therapy]] in conjunction with [[resistance exercise]]. Based upon two medical reviews and a [[meta-analysis]] of seven [[randomized controlled trial]]s, HMB supplementation can preserve or increase lean muscle mass and muscle strength in [[sarcopenic]] older adults.{{#tag:ref|The meta-analysis found that the average increase in muscle mass due to HMB supplementation in older adults was {{convert|0.35|kg|lbs}}. The [[95% confidence interval]] for the estimated increase in muscle mass due to HMB supplementation is {{convert|0.11|–|0.59|kg|lb}}.
The seven randomized controlled trials that were included in the meta-analysis contained a total of 147 older adults in the HMB [[Treatment and control groups|treatment groups]] and 140 older adults in the [[Treatment and control groups|control groups]]. The seven trials had durations of 2–11 months and the average duration of the studies, [[weighted average|weighted by their sample size]], was approximately 6 months.|name="Meta-analysis of efficacy in older adults"|group="note"}}{{cite journal | vauthors = Wu H, Xia Y, Jiang J, Du H, Guo X, Liu X, Li C, Huang G, Niu K | title = Effect of beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate supplementation on muscle loss in older adults: a systematic review and meta-analysis | journal = Archives of Gerontology and Geriatrics | volume = 61 | issue = 2 | pages = 168–175 | date = September 2015 | pmid = 26169182 | doi = 10.1016/j.archger.2015.06.020 | quote = Overall, this meta-analysis indicates that HMB can prevent lean body mass loss in older adults. But the effects of HMB on muscle strength and physical function appears to vary in different populations. Additional well-designed clinical studies are necessary to confirm the effectiveness of HMB in the prevention of loss of muscle strength and physical function. ... Mechanisms underlying the role of HMB in muscle regeneration have also been explored: results indicated that HMB enhances protein synthesis via upregulation of anabolic signaling pathways and attenuate proteolysis via downregulation of catabolic signaling pathways (Wilkinson et al., 2013). }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Holeček M | title = Beta-hydroxy-beta-methylbutyrate supplementation and skeletal muscle in healthy and muscle-wasting conditions | journal = Journal of Cachexia, Sarcopenia and Muscle | volume = 8 | issue = 4 | pages = 529–541 | date = August 2017 | pmid = 28493406 | pmc = 5566641 | doi = 10.1002/jcsm.12208 | quote = The reports summarized here indicate that HMB provides a number of benefits to subjects involved in strength-power and endurance sports. The effects on muscle mass and strength, particularly during resistance training, are likely related to the suppression of proteolysis and a positive effect on protein synthesis. Its benefits in aerobic performance are probably more associated with improved mitochondrial biogenesis and fat oxidation. Favourable effects on the recovery from exercise-induced damage may be related to the role of HMB as a precursor of cholesterol, which modulates membrane fluidity and affects ion channels, and membrane excitability. ... Studies have demonstrated that HMB can prevent the development of sarcopenia in elderly subjects and that the optimal action of HMB on muscle growth and strength occurs when it is combined with exercise. }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Rossi AP, D'Introno A, Rubele S, Caliari C, Gattazzo S, Zoico E, Mazzali G, Fantin F, Zamboni M | title = The Potential of β-Hydroxy-β-Methylbutyrate as a New Strategy for the Management of Sarcopenia and Sarcopenic Obesity | journal = Drugs & Aging | volume = 34| issue = 11| pages = 833–840| date = October 2017 | pmid = 29086232 | doi = 10.1007/s40266-017-0496-0 | quote = Clinical trials performed in older adults confirm that HMB can attenuate the progression of sarcopenia in elderly subjects. HMB supplementation results in an increase in skeletal muscle mass and strength in the elderly and its effect is even greater when combined with physical exercise.}} HMB does not appear to significantly affect fat mass in older adults. Preliminary clinical evidence suggests that HMB supplementation may also prevent [[muscle atrophy]] during [[bed rest]]. A growing body of evidence supports the efficacy of HMB in nutritional support for reducing, or even reversing, the loss of muscle mass, [[Muscle#Physiology|muscle function]], and [[Muscle#Strength|muscle strength]] that occurs in [[hypercatabolic]] disease states such as cancer [[cachexia]];{{cite journal | vauthors = Argilés JM, Campos N, Lopez-Pedrosa JM, Rueda R, Rodriguez-Mañas L | title = Skeletal Muscle Regulates Metabolism via Interorgan Crosstalk: Roles in Health and Disease | journal = Journal of the American Medical Directors Association | volume = 17 | issue = 9 | pages = 789–796 | date = September 2016 | pmid = 27324808 | doi = 10.1016/j.jamda.2016.04.019 | url = http://www.jamda.com/article/S1525-8610(16)30113-X/fulltext | quote = Studies suggest dietary protein and leucine or its metabolite β-hydroxy β-methylbutyrate (HMB) can improve muscle function, in turn improving functional performance. ... These have identified the leucine metabolite β-hydroxy β-methylbutyrate (HMB) as a potent stimulator of protein synthesis as well as an inhibitor of protein breakdown in the extreme case of cachexia. ... A growing body of evidence suggests HMB may help slow, or even reverse, the muscle loss experienced in sarcopenia and improve measures of muscle strength. ... However, dietary leucine does not provide a large amount of HMB: only a small portion, as little as 5%, of catabolized leucine is metabolized into HMB. ... Thus, although dietary leucine itself can lead to a modest stimulation of protein synthesis by producing a small amount of HMB, direct ingestion of HMB more potently affects such signaling, resulting in demonstrable muscle mass accretion. ... Indeed, a vast number of studies have found that supplementation of HMB to the diet may reverse some of the muscle loss seen in sarcopenia and in hypercatabolic disease. ... The overall treatment of muscle atrophy should include dietary supplementation with HMB, although the optimal dosage for each condition is still under investigation. ...
[http://www.jamda.com/cms/attachment/2060482578/2062671998/gr4_lrg.jpg Figure 4: Treatments for sarcopenia.] It is currently recommended that patients at risk of or suffering from sarcopenia consume a diet high in protein, engage in resistance exercise, and take supplements of the leucine metabolite HMB. }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Mullin GE | title = Nutrition supplements for athletes: potential application to malnutrition | journal = Nutrition in Clinical Practice | volume = 29 | issue = 1 | pages = 146–147 | date = February 2014 | pmid = 24336486 | doi = 10.1177/0884533613516130 | quote = There are a number of nutrition products on the market that are touted to improve sports performance. HMB appears to be the most promising and to have clinical applications to improve muscle mass and function. Continued research using this nutraceutical to prevent and/or improve malnutrition in the setting of muscle wasting is warranted. }} consequently, the authors of two 2016 reviews of the clinical evidence recommended that the prevention and treatment of sarcopenia and muscle wasting in general include supplementation with HMB, regular resistance exercise, and consumption of a [[high-protein diet]]. Clinical trials that used HMB for the treatment of muscle wasting have involved the administration of 3 grams of HMB per day under different dosing regimens. According to one review, an optimal dosing regimen is to administer it in one 1 gram dose, three times a day, since this ensures elevated plasma concentrations of HMB throughout the day; however, {{as of|June 2016|lc=y}} the best dosing regimen for muscle wasting conditions is still being investigated. Some branded products that contain HMB (i.e., certain formulations of Ensure and Juven) are [[medical food]]s that are intended to be used to provide nutritional support under the care of a doctor in individuals with [[muscle wasting]] due to [[HIV/AIDS]] or [[cancer]], to promote [[wound healing]] following surgery or injury, or when otherwise recommended by a medical professional.{{#tag:ref|{{cite web|title=Product Information: Ensure Enlive Advanced Therapeutic Nutrition Shake|publisher=Abbott Nutrition|url=http://static.abbottnutrition.com/cms-prod/abbottnutrition.com/img/Ensure-Enlive-Advanced-Therapeutic-Nutrition-Shake.pdf|accessdate=22 August 2016|date=9 August 2016|quote=
{{•}}Use under medical supervision.
{{•}}HMB + protein for muscle health.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012132214/http://static.abbottnutrition.com/cms-prod/abbottnutrition.com/img/Ensure-Enlive-Advanced-Therapeutic-Nutrition-Shake.pdf|archivedate=12 October 2016}}

{{cite web|title=Product Information: Juven|publisher=Abbott Nutrition|url=http://static.abbottnutrition.com/cms-prod/abbottnutrition.com/img/Juven.pdf|date=7 May 2016|accessdate=22 August 2016|quote=
{{•}}Administer orally or as a modular via feeding tube ...
{{•}}Use under medical supervision.
