{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=September 2014}} {{unreferenced|date=June 2013}} }}
'''Duplex strainer''' or twin basket strainer is a type of filter built into a fuel, oil or water piping system and it is used to remove large particles of dirt and [[debris]]. The duplex strainer system usually consists of two separate strainer baskets housings. The system also contains a valve handle placed between the two baskets to divert the flow of liquid to one strainer while the other is being cleaned. On some strainers, the valve will work automatically and the strainer will perform a self-cleaning operation.
These types of strainers are installed in pipeline systems where flow cannot be stopped. Depending upon their NB size they are capable of filtration up to 40 [[µm]]. Basket Strainers find use in industries where impurities are mostly solids. Unlike other types of strainers, it is easy to conduct maintenance on these strainers.
Duplex strainers are mainly used in various industries such as [[process industry]], power industry, chemical industry, oil and gas industry, pulp and paper industry, pharmaceutical industry, metals and mining industry, water and waste management, fire fighting industry, refineries and petrochemical plants. Strainers are used to remove hazardous elements that might cause partial or complete breakdown of operations if they get into the system.
==External links== * https://web.archive.org/web/20130228092604/http://www.tecmara.de/fileadmin/tecmara/PDFs/Filter/Englisch/Duplex-Strainer.pdf * http://www.bossmaninternational.com/Duplex_strainers.pdf [[Category:Filters]] [[Category:Filtration]] [[Category:Water treatment]] [[Category:Water industry]] [[Category:Petroleum industry]]

'''Economic evaluation''' is the process of systematic identification, measurement and valuation of the inputs and outcomes of two alternative activities, and the subsequent comparative analysis of these.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Drummond|first1=Michael|last2=Sculpher|first2=Mark|last3=Torrance|first3=George|last4=O'Brien|first4=Bernie|last5=Stoddart|first5=Greg|title=Methods for the Economic Evaluation of Health Care Programmes|date=2005|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=9780198529453|edition=3}}</ref> The purpose of economic evaluation is to identify the best course of action, based on the evidence available. It is most commonly employed in the context of [[health economics]] and [[health technology assessment]]; in the UK, the [[National Institute for Health and Care Excellence]] publishes guidelines for the conduct of economic evaluations.<ref>{{cite book|author1=National Institute for Health and Care Excellence|authorlink1=National Institute for Health and Care Excellence|title=Guide to the methods of technology appraisal 2013|date=2013|url=http://www.nice.org.uk/article/PMG9}}</ref>
==Types==
Economic evaluations can take a number of forms, namely: * [[Cost-benefit analysis]] * [[Cost-effectiveness analysis]] * [[Cost-utility analysis]] * [[Cost-consequences analysis]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Econ-stub}} [[Category:Health economics]]

{{Multiple issues| {{notability|date=July 2015}} {{Refimprove|date=January 2010}} }}
'''Emergen-C''' is an effervescent, powdered [[drink mix]] [[vitamin supplement]] manufactured by Alacer Corp. The Emergen-C product line was introduced in 1978.<ref name='About'>{{cite web|url=http://emergenc.com/index.php/misc/alacer |title=About Alacer Corp. |accessdate=2012-12-04}}</ref> Alacer was established as a private company in 1972, focusing on vitamin supplements containing [[vitamin C]]. In 2012, the company was acquired by [[Pfizer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20120227006543/en/Pfizer-Acquires-Alacer-Corp.-Leading-Vitamin-Supplements |title=Pfizer Acquires Alacer Corp., a Leading Vitamin Supplements Company|publisher=BusinessWire |date=2012-02-17 |accessdate=2012-12-04}}</ref><ref>[http://www.zacks.com/stock/news/91435/pfizer-tops-guides-in-line]</ref>
It contains, depending on the variety, 16 times the [[vitamin C]], 4 times the [[vitamin B12|vitamin B<sub>12</sub>]], and 5 times the [[vitamin B6|vitamin B<sub>6</sub>]] of the [[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]] [[Reference Daily Intake]] based on a 2000 [[calorie]] diet. Some versions include [[calcium]], [[glucosamine]], [[quercetin]] or [[lycopene]]. Studies have failed to establish evidence for the use of vitamin C megadoses as a cold remedy or in reducing cold incidences.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD000980.pub4 | title=Vitamin C for preventing and treating the common cold | journal=Reviews | last1 = Hemilä | first1 = Harri}}</ref>
==Manufacturing== Alacer manufactures its products in the United States, in [[Carlisle, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="FAQ">{{cite web|url=http://emergenc.com/index.php/misc/faq |title=Alacer Corp FAQ |accessdate=2012-12-04}}</ref>
==Ingredients== [[GMO]] ingredients are used. From the Alacer website: "We have chosen to source materials that are non-GMO whenever possible. That being said, we cannot guarantee that all of our raw materials are sourced from non-GMO ingredients and do not currently have this requirement in place for our vendors". Most products do not contain animal-derived ingredients, but some certain products contain [[chondroitin]] from cows, [[honey]], and [[vitamin D3|vitamin D<sub>3</sub>]] from wool.<ref>{{cite web|title=Is Emergen-C Vegan?|url=http://www.isitvegan.com/2012/02/25/is-emergen-c-vegan/|website=Is It Vegan?|accessdate=10 January 2016}}</ref>
== Class Action Lawsuit == In December 2013, a superior court judge preliminarily approved a $6.45 million settlement to a class-action lawsuit filed against Alacer Corp. for alleged deceptive marketing. The complaint, which was originally filed earlier in the year, alleged that the company misleadingly represented that the supplement would provide health benefits – including reducing the risk of or preventing colds and flu – without scientific evidence to support such claims. According to the settlement terms, class members may receive a refund of up to $36 with proof of purchase. (''Wong et al v. Alacer Corp.,'' Case No. CGC-12-519221, Superior Court of California County of San Francisco). A superior court judge gave final approval of the settlement to this lawsuit in June 2014.{{Citation needed |reason='no indication that this settlement was ever executed' |date=April 2017}}
==Outreach== In 1997, Alacer established The Emergen-C Fund, which has raised more than $650,000. This fund provides support to [[Vitamin Angels]], [[Surfrider Foundation]], [[Keep A Breast Foundation]], [[Young Survival Coalition]], and [[Whole Foods]]' Whole Planet Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emergenc.com/fund |title=Emergen-C Fund Charities |accessdate=2012-12-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121211043347/http://emergenc.com/fund |archivedate=2012-12-11 |df= }}</ref>
Alacer sponsors [[Operation Gratitude]], a volunteer organization that has sent care packages to U.S. troops in Iraq and Afghanistan.<ref name='About'/>
In 2008 Emergen-C teamed up with surf artist [[Jay Alders]] to create art for the packaging of their new product/flavor, Emergen-C Blue, with 25 cents donated to [[Surfrider Foundation]] for each box sold.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.surfersvillage.com/surfing/38799/news.htm |title=Emergen-C launches a new product to benefit Surfrider |date=2009-02-03 |website= |publisher=Surfersvillage.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204221123/http://www.surfersvillage.com/surfing/38799/news.htm |archivedate=February 4, 2010 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=2011-02-11 |quote= |ref= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.surfrider.org/partners/entry/emergen-c Emergen-C | Surfrider Foundation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203005235/http://www.surfrider.org/partners/entry/emergen-c |date=2013-12-03 }}. Retrieved 2013 November 29.</ref>
==See also== *[[Vitamin C megadosage]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.emergenc.com Emergen-C Official Website (US)] * [http://www.emergen-c.ca Emergen-C Official Website (Canada)] * [http://www.emergenc.co.uk Emergen-C Official Website (UK)]
[[Category:Dietary supplements]] [[Category:American brands]]

{{short description|A disorder of chronic intestinal inflammation}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Environmental enteropathy | synonyms = | image = Villous blunting in endoscopic biopsy.png | caption =Histological evidence of enteropathy (inflammatory infiltrate, villus blunting) seen in this intestinal biopsy from a child with malnutrition.<ref name=louis2017/> | alt =Tropical enteropathy, environmental enteric dysfunction | pronounce = | field =Gastroenterology | symptoms =Asymptomatic (most common), altered stool consistency, increased stool frequency, weight loss | complications =Malnutrition, malabsorption, growth stunting, developmental delay, impaired response to oral vaccines | onset = | duration =Chronic | types = | causes =Unsanitary food and water sources, fecal-oral contamination, chronic enteric infections, mucosal inflammation | risks = | diagnosis =Intestinal biopsy (gold standard), abnormal sugar absorption test, clinical (significantly more common) | differential =Tropical sprue | prevention =Sanitation | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Environmental enteropathy''' ('''EE''') (also known as '''tropical enteropathy''' or '''environmental enteric dysfunction''') is a disorder of chronic intestinal inflammation.<ref name=ali2016>{{cite journal|last1=Ali|first1=A|last2=Iqbal|first2=NT|last3=Sadiq|first3=K|title=Environmental enteropathy.|journal=Current Opinion in Gastroenterology|date=January 2016|volume=32|issue=1|pages=12–7|doi=10.1097/MOG.0000000000000226|pmid=26574871}}</ref><ref name=korpe2012>{{cite journal|last1=Korpe|first1=PS|last2=Petri WA|first2=Jr|title=Environmental enteropathy: critical implications of a poorly understood condition.|journal=Trends in Molecular Medicine|date=June 2012|volume=18|issue=6|pages=328–36|doi=10.1016/j.molmed.2012.04.007|pmid=22633998|pmc=3372657}}</ref><ref name=louis2017>{{Cite journal|last=Louis-Auguste|first=John|last2=Kelly|first2=Paul|date=2017-07-01|title=Tropical Enteropathies|journal=Current Gastroenterology Reports|language=en|volume=19|issue=7|pages=29|doi=10.1007/s11894-017-0570-0|pmid=28540669|pmc=5443857}}</ref> EE is most common amongst children living in low-resource settings.<ref name=ali2016/><ref name=korpe2012/><ref name=louis2017/> Acute symptoms are typically minimal or absent.<ref name=korpe2012/> EE can lead to [[Malnutrition in children|malnutrition]], [[anemia]] ([[iron-deficiency anemia]] and [[Anemia of chronic disease|anemia of chronic inflammation]]),<ref name=ali2016/> growth stunting, impaired brain development,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ngure|first1=FM|last2=Reid|first2=BM|last3=Humphrey|first3=JH|last4=Mbuya|first4=MN|last5=Pelto|first5=G|last6=Stoltzfus|first6=RJ|title=Water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH), environmental enteropathy, nutrition, and early child development: making the links.|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|date=January 2014|volume=1308|pages=118–28|doi=10.1111/nyas.12330|pmid=24571214}}</ref><ref name=bhutta2017>{{Cite journal|last=Bhutta|first=Zulfiqar A.|last2=Guerrant|first2=Richard L.|last3=Nelson|first3=Charles A.|date=2017-04-01|title=Neurodevelopment, Nutrition, and Inflammation: The Evolving Global Child Health Landscape|journal=Pediatrics|language=en|volume=139|issue=Supplement 1|pages=S12–S22|doi=10.1542/peds.2016-2828d|pmid=28562245}}</ref><ref name=john2017>{{Cite journal|last=John|first=Chandy C.|last2=Black|first2=Maureen M.|last3=Nelson|first3=Charles A.|date=2017-04-01|title=Neurodevelopment: The Impact of Nutrition and Inflammation During Early to Middle Childhood in Low-Resource Settings|journal=Pediatrics|language=en|volume=139|issue=Supplement 1|pages=S59–S71|doi=10.1542/peds.2016-2828h|pmid=28562249|pmc=5694688}}</ref> and impaired response to oral [[vaccination]]s.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Oriá|first1=RB|last2=Murray-Kolb|first2=LE|last3=Scharf|first3=RJ|last4=Pendergast|first4=LL|last5=Lang|first5=DR|last6=Kolling|first6=GL|last7=Guerrant|first7=RL|title=Early-life enteric infections: relation between chronic systemic inflammation and poor cognition in children.|journal=Nutrition Reviews|date=June 2016|volume=74|issue=6|pages=374–86|doi=10.1093/nutrit/nuw008|pmid=27142301|pmc=4892302}}</ref><ref name=czerkinsky2015>{{Cite journal|last=Czerkinsky|first=Cecil|last2=Holmgren|first2=Jan|date=2015-06-19|title=Vaccines against enteric infections for the developing world|journal=Phil. Trans. R. Soc. B|language=en|volume=370|issue=1671|pages=20150142|doi=10.1098/rstb.2015.0142|pmid=25964464|pmc=4527397}}</ref>
The cause of EE is multifactorial. Overall, exposure to contaminated food and water leads to a generalized state of intestinal inflammation.<ref name=ali2016/><ref name=korpe2012/><ref name=louis2017/> The inflammatory response results in multiple pathological changes to the gastrointestinal tract: [[atrophy|Smaller villi]], larger crypts (called [[intestinal crypts|crypt hyperplasia]]), increased [[intestinal permeability|permeability]], and inflammatory cell build-up within the intestines.<ref name="korpe2012" /><ref name="louis2017" /><ref name="prendergast2012">{{cite journal|last1=Prendergast|first1=A|last2=Kelly|first2=P|title=Enteropathies in the developing world: neglected effects on global health.|journal=The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene|date=May 2012|volume=86|issue=5|pages=756–63|doi=10.4269/ajtmh.2012.11-0743|pmid=22556071|pmc=3335677}}</ref> These changes result in poor absorption of food, vitamins and minerals.
Standardized, clinically practical diagnostic criteria do not exist. The most accurate diagnostic test is intestinal biopsy. However, this test is invasive and unnecessary for most patients.<ref name="ali2016" />
Prevention is the strongest and most reliable option for preventing EE and its effects. Therefore, prevention and treatment of EE are often discussed together.<ref name="prendergast2012" /><ref name="humphrey2009">{{cite journal|last1=Humphrey|first1=JH|date=2009|title=Child undernutrition, tropical enteropathy, toilets, and handwashing.|journal=Lancet|volume=374|issue=9694|pages=1032–5|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(09)60950-8|pmid=19766883}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mbuya|first1=MN|last2=Humphrey|first2=JH|title=Preventing environmental enteric dysfunction through improved water, sanitation and hygiene: an opportunity for stunting reduction in developing countries.|journal=Maternal & child nutrition|date=May 2016|volume=12 Suppl 1|pages=106–20|doi=10.1111/mcn.12220|pmid=26542185|pmc=5019251}}</ref>
== Signs and symptoms == Environmental enteropathy is believed to result in chronic [[malnutrition]] and subsequent [[growth stunting]] (low height-for-age measurement) as well as other child development deficits.
===Short-term === EE is rarely symptomatic and is considered a [[subclinical]] condition.<ref name=ali2016/><ref name=louis2017/><ref name=korpe2012/> However, adults may have mild symptoms or malabsorption such as altered stool consistency, increased stool frequency and weight loss.
===Long-term === * Malnutrition <ref name="ali2016" /><ref name="korpe2012" /> ** EE causes [[Malnutrition in children|malnutrition]] by way of both [[malabsorption]] and nutritional deficiencies. * Growth and physical development <ref name="prendergast2012" /> ** The first two years (and the prior 9 months of fetal life) are critical for linear growth. Stunting is an easy to measure symptom of these child development deficits. * Neurocognitive (brain development) <ref name="bhutta2017" /><ref name="john2017" /> * Effect on oral vaccination <ref name="czerkinsky2015" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gilmartin|first=Allissia A.|last2=Petri|first2=William A.|date=2015-06-19|title=Exploring the role of environmental enteropathy in malnutrition, infant development and oral vaccine response|journal=Phil. Trans. R. Soc. B|language=en|volume=370|issue=1671|pages=20140143|doi=10.1098/rstb.2014.0143|pmid=25964455|pmc=4527388}}</ref> ** Many oral [[vaccines]], both live and non-living, have proven to be less immunogenic or less protective when administered to [[infants]], children or adults living in low socioeconomic conditions in [[developing countries]] than they are when used in [[industrialized countries]]. Widespread EE is hypothesized to be a contributing cause for this observation. [[File:Poliodrops.jpg|thumb|Child receiving oral polio vaccine. There is some evidence that the enteric dysfunction characteristic of EE may impair the efficacy of oral vaccinations.]]
== Causes and mechanism ==
The development of EE is multifactorial, but predominantly associated with chronic exposure to contaminated food and water. This is especially true in environments where widespread [[open defecation]] and lack of [[sanitation]] are common.<ref name="ali2016" /><ref name="korpe2012" /><ref name="louis2017" />
Long-term exposure to environmental pathogens leads to a generalized state of intestinal inflammation. Chronic inflammation leads to both functional and structural changes which alter gut permeability and ability of the intestine to absorb nutrients.<ref name="ali2016" /><ref name="korpe2012" /><ref name="louis2017" /> [[File:Villous atrophy in endoscopic images.png|thumb|Evidence of villous atrophy in endoscopic images of the small intestine.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Louis-Auguste|first=John|last2=Kelly|first2=Paul|date=2017-07-01|title=Tropical Enteropathies|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11894-017-0570-0|journal=Current Gastroenterology Reports|language=en|volume=19|issue=7|pages=29|doi=10.1007/s11894-017-0570-0|issn=1522-8037|pmid=28540669|pmc=5443857}}</ref>]] Specifically, structural changes within the intestine include [[atrophy|smaller villi]], larger crypts (called [[intestinal crypts|crypt hyperplasia]]), increased permeability, and inflammatory cell build-up within the intestines. These changes result in poor absorption of food, vitamins and minerals – or "modest [[malabsorption]]".<ref name="ali2016" /><ref name="korpe2012" /><ref name="louis2017" /> [[File:Environmental enteropathy - mechanism model.png|thumb|Simplified mechanism outlining causes and effects of EE.]]
==Diagnosis== The current gold standard diagnostic test for EE is intestinal biopsy and histological analysis. Histological changes observed include:<ref name="louis2017" /> * Villous blunting * Crypt hypertrophy * Villous fusion * Mucosal inflammation However, this procedure is considered too invasive, complex and expensive to be implemented as standard of care.<ref name="ali2016" /> As a result, there are various research efforts underway to identify [[biomarker]]s associated with EE, which could serve as less invasive, yet representative, tools to screen for and identify EE from stool samples.<ref name="ali2016" />
In an effort to identify simple, accurate diagnostic tests for EE, the [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]] (BMGF) has established an EE biomarkers consortium as part of their [[Global Grand Challenges]] initiative (specifically, the Discover Biomarkers of Gut Function challenge).<ref name="ali2016" />
So far, various biomarkers have been selected and studied based on the current understanding of EE pathophysiology:<ref name="ali2016" /> * [[Intestinal mucosal barrier|Gut permeability]]/barrier function ** Dual sugar permeability ([[lactose]]-to-[[mannitol]] ratio) * Intestinal inflammation ** [[Alpha-1 antitrypsin|Alpha-1 anti-trypsin]] ** [[Neopterin]] ** [[Myeloperoxidase]] * [[Exocrine gland|Exocrine]] (hormonal) markers * Bacterial translocation markers ** Endotoxin core antibody * Markers of systemic inflammation ** [[Alpha-1-B glycoprotein|Alpha-1 glycoprotein]] ** [[C-reactive protein]] (CRP)  It is postulated that the limited of understanding of EE is partially due to the paucity of reliable biomarkers, making it difficult for researchers to track the epidemiology of the condition and assess the efficacy of interventions.<ref name="prendergast2012" />
=== Classification === In the 1960s, researchers reported a syndrome of non-specific [[histopathological]] and functional changes to the [[small intestine]] in individuals living in unsanitary conditions.<ref name=korpe2012/> This syndrome was observed predominantly in tropical regions across Latin America, sub-Saharan Africa and Asia. The geographic distribution of the syndrome lead to the original term of "tropical enteropathy" (sometimes also "tropical jejunopathy").<ref name=korpe2012/>
Following initial reports, further investigation revealed that these symptoms were not specific to tropical climates. For example, individuals in more wealthy tropical countries, such as Qatar and Singapore, did not exhibit these symptoms.<ref name=louis2017/> Similarly, subsequent studies have shown this condition to be common across the developing world, closely associated with impoverished conditions but independent of climate or geography.<ref name=louis2017/><ref name=prendergast2012/> As a result, the term "environmental enteropathy" was introduced to specify that this condition is not only found in tropical areas and is believed to be caused by environmental factors.<ref name=korpe2012/>
==Prevention and treatment== [[File:AFRICA BASIN AND PITCHER FOR WASHING HANDS.jpg|thumb|Sanitary measures, such as hand-washing before preparing food, is recommended in the prevention of EE.]]
Prevention focuses on improving sanitation of water and food sources.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mbuya|first=Mduduzi N. N.|last2=Humphrey|first2=Jean H.|date=2016-05-01|title=Preventing environmental enteric dysfunction through improved water, sanitation and hygiene: an opportunity for stunting reduction in developing countries|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/mcn.12220/abstract|journal=Maternal & Child Nutrition|language=en|volume=12|pages=106–120|doi=10.1111/mcn.12220|issn=1740-8709|pmid=26542185|pmc=5019251}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ngure|first=Francis M.|last2=Reid|first2=Brianna M.|last3=Humphrey|first3=Jean H.|last4=Mbuya|first4=Mduduzi N.|last5=Pelto|first5=Gretel|last6=Stoltzfus|first6=Rebecca J.|date=2014-01-01|title=Water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH), environmental enteropathy, nutrition, and early child development: making the links|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/nyas.12330/abstract|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=1308|issue=1|pages=118–128|doi=10.1111/nyas.12330|issn=1749-6632|pmid=24571214}}</ref>
Another important factor might be contaminated soil in child play spaces, often caused by the presence of livestock such as chicken in the household. Creating a clean play space might therefore be an effective preventive measure for EE in toddlers.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=George|first1=Christine Marie|title=Enteric Infections in Young Children are Associated with Environmental Enteropathy and Impaired Growth|journal=Tropical medicine and international health|date=11 December 2017|volume=23|issue=1|doi=10.1111/tmi.13002|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/tmi.13002/full|accessdate=11 January 2018|pages=26–33}}</ref>
Treatment focuses on addressing the central components of intestinal inflammation, bacterial overgrowth and nutritional supplementation.<ref name="ali2016" />
==Research initiatives== There are multiple large-field, multi-country research initiatives focusing on strategies to prevent and treat EE.<ref name="prendergast2012" /> * The [https://fnih.org/what-we-do/current-research-programs/mal-ed MAL-ED] project * The [http://aliveandthrive.org/ Alive and Thrive] nutrition project * The [http://blogs.cornell.edu/centirgroup/research-projects/shine/ Sanitation, Hygiene and Infant Nutrition Efficacy (SHINE) Trial] (ClinicalTrials.gov identifier: [https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01824940 NCT01824940]) * The [http://water.stanford.edu/research/water-sanitation-and-health/wash-benefits-bangladesh-kenya WASH Benefits] Study {{-}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://mal-ed.fnih.org/ MAL-ED], The Interactions of Malnutrition & Enteric Infections: Consequences for Child Health and Development research project. *[https://www.defeatdd.org/ Defeat Diarrheal Disease (DefeatDD) initiative] & [http://www.defeatdd.org/sites/default/files/node-images/PATH_6-20-16-Final.pdf infographic]
{{Diseases of Poverty}}

The '''European Health Telematics Observatory''' (EHTO) is a [[non-profit]] [[organization]] which collects, analyses and makes available in a user-friendly form information on developments in the field of health [[telematics]]. The organization contributes to the deployment of health telematics applications and standards in [[Europe]]. EHTO works on the dissemination of results of the European Telematics Applications Programme (TAP) of the Fourth [[Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development|Framework Programme]] to the European [[health care]] sector.
==Participants== * [[Portugal]]: [[Portugal Telecom]] * [[Belgium]]: RAMIT (Research in Advanced Medical Informatics and Telematics) * [[France]]: CNEH (Centre National de l’Equipement Hospitalier) * [[Ireland]]: IHC Centre for Health Informatics * [[Spain]]: IETT Ingenieria y Prevencion de Riesgos * [[Greece]]: BIOTRAST * [[Finland]]: [[VTT]] Information Technology
==See also== * [[Health informatics]] * [[European Institute for Health Records]] * European Health Telematics Association (EHTEL) * [[ProRec]]
==Sources== * [http://www.katelco.kz/UNESCO/presentations/HC/Thienpont.doc EHTO] (Doc) * [http://cordis.europa.eu/telematics/ European Telematics]
==External links== * [http://www.ehto.be/ European Health Telematics Observatory]
[[Category:Health informatics organisations]] [[Category:Information technology organisations in Europe]] [[Category:Health and the European Union]]

[[Image:Eurorec logo 070503.jpg|thumb|200px|right|EuroRec logo]] The '''European Institute for Health Records''' or '''EuroRec Institute''' is a non-profit organization founded in 2002 as part of the [[ProRec]] initiative. On 13 May 2003, the institute was established as a non-profit organization under [[France|French]] law. Current President of EuroRec is Prof. [[Dipak Kalra]]. The institute is involved in the promotion of high quality [[Electronic Health Record]] systems in the [[European Union]]. One of the main missions of the institute is to support, as the European authorised certification body, EHRs certification development, testing and assessment by defining functional and other criteria.
The objectives of the institute are: # To federate the established ProRec centres that comply with a set of explicit criteria. # To develop specifically those activities that cannot be handled at the level of ProRec centres and/or within their scope, according to the principle of subsidiarity and in view of both synergy and [[economy of scale]].
==European projects==
===ARGOS=== The main goal of the ARGOS project was to contribute to creating "Transatlantic Observatory for Meeting Global Health Policy Challenges through ICT-Enabled Solutions" to allow promotion of "Common Methods for Responding to Global eHealth Challenges in the EU and the US".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/argos.cfm|title=ARGOS|accessdate=2013-01-06 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref> The results are used to provide various users recommendations in sustaining co-ordinated actions. It is important to both Europe and America of United States because:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/argos.cfm|title=ARGOS|accessdate=2013-01-06 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>
*There is a barrier in fostering healthcare globally as citizens travel and migrate *It will help improve their products to better promote themselves in global markets *The global experiences will become important information for both Europe and America
Through the challenges of enhancing ehealth strategy development, promoting benefits of consistent strategies and supporting large scale ehealth infrastructure implementations will allow Europe and United States researchers and policy makers gain mutual understanding and learning.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/argos.cfm|title=ARGOS|accessdate=2013-01-06 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>
The main topics that were address within this project was; ehealth interoperability an EHR certifications, establishing an approach and identification of indicators of the usage and benefits of ehealth, and aiding clinicians in diagnosis and treatment of rare diseases through human physiology and disease modelling and simulation. However the project has highlighted challenges in establishing competent ehealth informatics staff.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/argos.cfm|title=ARGOS|accessdate=2013-01-06 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref> There are variations of understanding, qualification and definition of workforce requirements through Europe and The United States.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/argos.cfm|title=ARGOS|accessdate=2013-01-06 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>
===HITCH: Healthcare Interoperability Testing and Conformance Harmonisation=== HITCH project begun 01/01/10 and ended on the 30/06/11. The objective of this project was to involve major stakeholders in defining and agreeing a roadmap that is essential to the foundation for the Interoperability Conformance Testing of information systems in the field of healthcare.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/hitch.cfm|title=HITCH |accessdate=2013-06-06 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref> HITCH project aims to propose plans on achieving interoperability conformance testing foundation starting 2011 through evaluating existing approaches and identifying potential gaps in initiatives.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/hitch.cfm|title=HITCH |accessdate=2013-06-06 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref> The roadmap will identify specific needs in improving processes and tools development that will support research. The roadmap will be tested in real-world settings with healthcare IT applications to determine the next logicals steps in establishing a credibility amongst major stakeholders (vendors, users, patients and authorities).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/hitch.cfm|title=HITCH |accessdate=2013-06-06 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>
===Q-REC: European Quality Labelling and Certification of Electronic Health Record systems (EHRs)=== The Q-REC project started 01/01/06 and finished on 30/06/08. It is a project that is a Specific Support Action and its objective is to supplement the existing e-Health ERA Co-ordination Project "Towards the establishment of a European e Health Research Area". It aims is to create an credible, sustainable and efficient means in certifying EHR system in Europe by concentrating EHR Systems Quality Labeling and Certification Development, Resources for EHR interoperatability, and Benchmarking Services.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/rd/pastproject_q-rec.cfm|title=Q-REC |accessdate=2013-12-05 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>
Some of the goals stated by Q-REC and EuroREC webpage <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/rd/pastproject_q-rec.cfm|title=Q-REC |accessdate=2013-12-05 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref> includes:
''' EHR Systems Quality Labelling and Certification Development'''
*Developing a modern report on EHR-Certification Schemas that has been implemented in at least three European countries; *Completing a Pan-European Requirements Assay; *Proposing a Labelling Terminology and Functional Profiles for EHRs to be certified; *Comparing and harmonising the EHR-Certification Procedures at a European level; *Drafting Model Certification Guidelines and Procedures; *Planning the Validation of the Guidelines.
''' Resources for EHR Interoperability'''
*Producing a register for Conformance Criteria and Guidance Documents for obtaining EHR Certification; *Establishing EHR Archetypes guidelines and inventory; *Establishing a registration process for Coding Schemes in Europe (as mandated by CEN/TC 251); *Providing relevant EHR related standards inventory;
'''Benchmarking Services'''
*Defining services that uses benchmarking for Manual for Quality Labelling and Certification; *Preparing the Business Plan for new EHR-Certification related Services
This project was done with EuroRec institute whose mission was to promote high quality EHRs throughout Europe. Through its networks and its centres acting as platforms along with the collaboration with eHealth ERA consortium and European Health Care Authorities (HCA)/ Ministries groups, EuroRec has provided various methods in assessing the needs and optimal choice methods for quality labelling and certification of EHRs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/rd/pastproject_q-rec.cfm|title=Q-REC |accessdate=2013-12-05 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>
===RIDE: A Roadmap for Interoperability of [[eHealth]] Systems in Support of COM 356 with Special Emphasis on Semantic Interoperability=== RIDE is a project that aims to provide a solid foundation for the action plans of eHealth Communication COM 356. It begun on 01/01/06 and ended on 31/12/07. Through research and development into the interoperability of eHealth systems, meaningful recommendations can be made for actions at a European level. The lack of complete harmonisation between clinical practice, terminology and EHR systems have highlighted that there is an unrealistic expectation in developing a single universally clinical data model. Hence the RIDE project objective is to provide a roadmap through focusing on current limitations of policies and strategies in solutions for ehealth interoperability and assessing health's European best practices in regards to providing semantic interoperability.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/rd/pastproject_ride.cfm |title=RIDE|accessdate=2013-12-05 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>
===EHR-IMPLEMENT: National policies for EHR Implementation in the European area: social and organizational issues=== The objective of EHR-IMPLEMENT is to provide best practice, policy and strategic recommendations in the implementation of EHR in Europe. This is done though the collection and analysis of EHR implementations in various countries. Previous EHR projects have always addressed the technological area in EHR. Other commonly overlooked in projects, the EHR-IMPLEMENT will focus the social and organisational on a broad national initiative, as these factor may potentially hinder, if not ruin the EHR implementation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/ehr_implement.cfm|title=National policies for EHR Implementation in the European area: social and organizational issues|accessdate=2013-12-05 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>
This project comprised a case study approach and a foused survey at a European level. It aims to analyse and collect information on best practices and eloborate recommendations for policy makers to facilitate EHR into member states.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/ehr_implement.cfm|title=National policies for EHR Implementation in the European area: social and organizational issues|accessdate=2013-12-05 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref>
According to EuroREC,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurorec.org/RD/ehr_implement.cfm|title=National policies for EHR Implementation in the European area: social and organizational issues|accessdate=2013-12-05 |last= |first= |year= 2013 |format= webpage |publisher= |doi= |quote= }}</ref> these are the main objectives of the projects:
*Analysis of national policies and strategies for the implementation of EHR *Conducting a survey regarding policy and action plans for National Implementation of EHR into Member States. *Investigating EHR users in the implementation process. *Raising issues of EHR implementation *Identifying best practices towards EHR implementation in Europe *Promoting information sharing and mutual learning through supporting the development of a community of scientific experts, technical personnel and National Health System representatives *Providing results and recommendations of the project amongst stakeholders across Europe
==See also== * [[CEN/TC 251]] * [[Canada Health Infoway]] * [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] (USA) * [[Clinical Document Architecture]] (CDA) * [[Directorate-General for Information Society and Media (European Commission)]] * [[EHRcom]] * [[European Federation for Medical Informatics]] (EFMI) * [[European Health Telematics Association]] (EHTEL) * [[European Health Telematics Observatory]] (EHTO) * [[Health Informatics Service Architecture]] (HISA) * [[Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act]] (HIPAA, USA) * [[Health Level 7]] * [[International Classification of Primary Care]] (ICPC) * [[KMEHR|Kind Messages for Electronic Healthcare Record]] (KMEHR) * [[National Resource Center for Health Information Technology]] * [[openEHR]] Foundation
==References== <references />
==Sources== * Iakovidis I, Purcarea O., ''eHealth in Europe: from Vision to Reality'', Stud Health Technol Inform. 2008;134:163-8 * Richardson R., ''eHealth for Europe'', Stud Health Technol Inform. 2003;96:151-6
==External links== * [http://www.eurorec.org/ European Institute for Health Records] * [http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20080215062335/http://www.centc251.org/ CEN/TC 125] (European Standardization of Health Informatics) * [http://ec.europa.eu/information_society/doc/qualif/health/COM_2004_0356_F_EN_ACTE.pdf COM (2004) 356 final] * [http://cordis.europa.eu/ist/health/index.html Directorate H - ICT For Citizens and Businesses] (Unit H1 - ICT for Health)

revision.text:
An '''extremotroph''' (from Latin ''{{lang|la|extremus}}'' meaning "extreme" and Greek ''{{lang|grc-Latn|troph}}'' ({{lang|grc|τροφ}}) meaning "food") is an organism that feeds on matter that is not typically considered to be food to most life on Earth. "These anthropocentric definitions that we make of [[Extremophile|extremophily]] and extremotrophy focus on a single environmental extreme but many extremophiles may fall into multiple categories, for example, organisms living inside hot rocks deep under the Earth's surface."<ref>Horikoshi, Koki (2010) ''Extremophiles Handbook'', pg. 5</ref>
== Examples == *''[[Pestalotiopsis microspora]]'': plastic eater *''[[Halomonas titanicae]]'': metal eater<ref>[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/12/101210-new-species-bacteria-metal-titanic-wreck-science/ New Bacteria Found on Titanic; Eats Metal<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *''[[Geotrichum candidum]]'': compact disk eater<ref>[http://www.nature.com/news/2001/010627/full/news010628-11.html Fungus eats CD : Nature News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *''[[Aspergillus fumigatus]]'': [[printed circuit board]] eater<ref>Kirksey, Kirk (2005) ''Computer Factoids: Tales from the High-Tech Underbelly'', pg. 74</ref> *''[[Deinococcus radiodurans]]'': radioactive waste eater
== Industrial uses == Extremotrophs are used as [[bioremediation]] and [[biodegradation]] agents.
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Lithoautotroph]] *[[Chemotroph]] *[[Extremophile]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==

revision.text:
The Healthcare system in [[Kazakhstan]] is a post-Soviet healthcare system under reform.
== Overview ==
Life expectancy at birth in Kazakhstan is 148th in the world, below most developed nations and some developing nations. It is below the average life expectancy for the European Union.<ref>https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2102rank.html CIA Factbook, Life expectancy by country.</ref><ref>https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2091rank.html CIA Factbook, Infant mortality rate by country.</ref>
The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), in 2000, ranked the Kazakhstani healthcare system as the 64th in overall performance, and 135th by overall level of health (among 191 member nations included in the study).
==History== The quality of healthcare, which remained entirely under state control in 2006, declined in the post-Soviet era because of insufficient funding and the loss of technical experts through emigration. Between 1989 and 2001, the ratio of [[physician|doctors]] per 10,000 inhabitants fell by 15% , to 34.6, and the ratio of hospital beds per 10,000 inhabitants fell by 46%, to 74. By 2005 those indicators had recovered somewhat, to 55 and 77, respectively. Since 1991, health care has consistently lacked adequate government funding; in 2005 only 2.5% of [[gross domestic product]] went for that purpose. A government health reform program aims to increase that figure to 4% in 2010. A compulsory [[health insurance]] system has been in the planning stages for several years. Wages for health workers are extremely low, and equipment is in critically short supply. The main foreign source of medical equipment is Japan. Because of cost, the emphasis of treatment increasingly is on outpatient care instead of the hospital care preferred under the Soviet system. The health system is in crisis in rural areas such as the [[Aral Sea]] region, where health is most affected by [[pollution]].<ref name=cp>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Kazakhstan.pdf Kazakhstancountry profile]. [[Library of Congress]] [[Federal Research Division]] (December 2006). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].''</ref>
The most common diseases are [[Respiratory disease|respiratory infections]], [[Cardiovascular disease|cardiovascular conditions]], and [[tuberculosis]]. Since 2000, the incidence of [[human immunodeficiency virus]] (HIV) has increased, as has the incidence of environment-linked [[cancers]]. In 2003 an estimated 23,000 citizens had HIV. Because of increasing numbers of people in high-risk categories, such as female sex workers and intravenous [[narcotics]] users, experts forecast an increase in that figure. In 2003 an estimated 80 percent of cases were narcotics-related. In 2006 an outbreak of juvenile HIV caused by improper hospital techniques gained national attention. In the first nine months of 2006, some 1,285 new cases were reported officially.<ref name=cp/>
37 mothers died per 100,000 live births in 2009. The maternal mortality rate had gone down slightly in comparison to 2008.<ref>http://www.inwent.org/ez/articles/197402/index.en.shtml</ref>
Officials reported very high numbers for [[Suicide in Kazakhstan|suicides in Kazakhstan]].
==Healthcare System==
'''Healthcare in Kazakhstan''' is provided by a network of primary, secondary and tertiary care facilities. Healthcare facilities are largely owned and operated by the [[public sector]] represented by the Ministry of Health. Health insurance is now primarily provided by the government in the public sector.
==Providers== [[Healthcare provider]]s in Kazakhstan encompass individual healthcare personnel, healthcare facilities and medical products.
==Facilities== {{Main|Hospitals in Kazakhstan}}
The [[public hospital]]s share of total hospital capacity has remained relatively stable (about 70%) for decades. There are also [[For-profit hospital|privately owned for-profit hospitals]] as well as [[public hospital|government hospitals]] in some locations, mainly owned by county and city governments.
There is a nationwide system of government-owned medical facilities open to the general public. The national [[Department of Defense of Kazakhstan|Department of Defense]] operates field hospitals as well as permanent hospitals (the [[Military Health System]]), to provide military-funded care to active military personnel.
[[Hospital]]s provide some outpatient care in their emergency rooms and specialty clinics, but primarily exist to provide inpatient care. Hospital [[emergency department]]s and [[urgent care]] centers are sources of sporadic problem-focused care. [[Hospice]] services for the terminally ill who are expected to live six months or less are most commonly subsidized by charities and government. Prenatal, [[family planning]] care is government-funded [[obstetric]] and [[gynaecological]] specialty and provided in primary care facilities, and are usually staffed by nurse practitioners (midwives).
A big share of medical health care is delivered through a vast network of primary care facilities called ambulatories and policlinics.
== [[Ministry of Health of Kazakhstan|Ministry of Health]] ==
One of executive branches in Kazakhstani government to control, regulate and organize the delivery of social services in [[public health]] and medical care. One of the office head was [[Salidat Kayirbekova]].
== Medical Universities == * [[Kazakh National Medical University]] * [[Qaraghandy State Medical University|Karaganda State Medical University]]
== [[National Medical Holding]] ==
National Medical Holding is an experimental health system located in capital city [[Astana]]. Its purpose is to be "medical cluster", so new health technologies could be acquired, developed and disseminated across the nation. It comprises several [[hospital]]s under centralized management, and as of 2012 is subordinated to [[Nazarbayev University]].
==List of National Medical Holding's subsidiaries== {{Unbulleted list| |National Research Center for Maternal and Child Health |Republican Diagnostic Center |[[National Research Cardiac Surgery Center]] |Republican Research Center for Neurosurgery |Republican Research Center for Emergency Care |National Children's Rehabilitation Center }}
==Non-governmental organizations==
Multiple domestic and international health [[NGO]]s conduct their work in Kazakhstan.
== Quality of Care in Kazakhstan ==
Enacted in 2010, new Code of Health proposed several changes in existing procedures in healthcare quality assurance.
==External links== * [http://www.mzsr.gov.kz/en Ministry of Healthcare and Social Development Kazakhstan] * [http://www.khp.kz/ Kazakhstan Health & Prosperity]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Europe topic|Health in}} {{Asia topic|Health in}}
[[Category:Health in Kazakhstan| ]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/199.91.56.26|199.91.56.26]] ([[User talk:199.91.56.26|talk]]) to last revision by Oshwah. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
The '''physical and mental health of [[Abraham Lincoln]]''' has been the subject of both contemporaneous commentary and subsequent hypotheses by historians and scholars.
==Physical health==
Despite the following occurrences, Lincoln's health up until middle age was fairly good for his day.<ref name=alh>{{cite web |url=http://www.abrahamlincolnsclassroom.org/Library/newsletter.asp?ID=25&CRLI=105 |publisher=The Lincoln Institute |title=Abraham Lincoln's Health |accessdate=2009-10-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Shutes |first=Milton H. |title=Lincoln's Emotional Life |page=103 |year=1957 |asin=B001OKE1F0 |publisher=Dorrance & Company }}</ref>
===Childhood===
There were fears for young Lincoln's life during a 24-hour period of unconsciousness that followed a horse kicking him in the head. He was nine years old when this occurred.
===Infectious disease===
* '''Malaria''': Lincoln had [[malaria]] at least twice. The first was in 1830, along with the rest of his family.<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraphs 2001-2007.</ref> They had just arrived in [[Illinois]] that year. The second episode was in the summer of 1835, while living in [[Lincoln's New Salem|New Salem]]. Lincoln was then so ill, he was sent to a neighbor's house to be medicated and cared for.<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], pages 385-386.</ref> * '''Syphilis''': Claims that Lincoln had [[syphilis]] about 1835 have been controversial. The most recent analysis by a physician accepts the diagnosis.<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], pages 390-400.</ref> All biographers reject the claim. Lincoln's law partner, friend and biographer [[William Herndon (lawyer)|William Herndon]] said Lincoln contracted the disease, specifically stating that "Lincoln told me this."<ref>{{cite book |title=The Hidden Lincoln: From the Letters and Papers of William H. Herndon |publisher=Viking Press |year=1938 |page=259 |author=Hertz, Emanuel (ed.)}} </ref> Herndon, believing both [[Mary Todd Lincoln|Mary Todd]] and Abraham Lincoln had syphilis, suspected it in the premature death of 3 Lincoln children. Abe Lincoln was known to take mercury, presumably for his condition.<ref>{{cite journal| pmc=1200645 | pmid=16200093 | volume=17 | issue=1 | title=Facts and ideas from anywhere | year=2004 | journal=Proc (Bayl Univ Med Cent) | pages=89–94 | last1 = Roberts | first1 = WC | doi=10.1080/08998280.2004.11927961}}</ref> There is no physical evidence that Lincoln had the disease, but physical evidence would not necessarily be expected, given that 50% of infections do not progress beyond a transient local infection, even without treatment.<ref>{{cite book |title=Neurosyphilis |publisher=Oxford University Press |year=1946 |page=4 |author=Merritt, H. Houston|display-authors=etal}} </ref> Syphilis was a common worry among young men before the introduction of penicillin<ref>{{cite book|author=Douglas L. Wilson|title=Honor's Voice: The Transformation of Abraham Lincoln|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KCM50uZMsQMC&pg=PA129|year=2011|publisher=Random House Digital, Inc.|pages=129, 184|isbn=9780307765819}}</ref> but this is not unexpected, given the commonness of syphilis in that era. Writing in 2003, biographer [[David Herbert Donald|David Donald]] declared, "Modern physicians who have sifted the evidence agree that Lincoln never contracted the disease,"<ref>{{cite book|author=David Herbert Donald|title=We Are Lincoln Men: Abraham Lincoln and His Friends|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OjyfM61m620C&pg=PA99|year=2004|publisher=Simon and Schuster|page=99|isbn=9780743254700}}</ref> however, these physicians have never published their analyses. * '''Smallpox''': Lincoln contracted [[smallpox]] shortly after delivering the [[Gettysburg Address]] in November 1863. Long thought to have been only a mild case, recent work suggests it was a serious illness.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Goldman AS |author2=Schmalstieg FC Jr. |title= Abraham Lincoln's Gettysburg illness. |journal= J Med Biogr |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages= 104–110 |year=2007 |pmid= 17551612 |doi=10.1258/j.jmb.2007.06-14}}</ref><ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], pages 411-431.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,273560,00.html |title=Study: Abraham Lincoln Nearly Died From Smallpox in 1863 |publisher=FoxNews.com |date=2007-05-21 |first=Jeanna |last=Bryner |accessdate=2009-10-13}}</ref> Although it did not debilitate Lincoln, the disease did significantly affect his White House routine, and limited the advisors with whom he could meet.<ref name=alh/> While caring for him, Lincoln's valet [[William H. Johnson]] contracted the disease and ultimately died from it.
===Trauma===
Lincoln died from a bullet wound to the head in 1865. His other episodes of adult trauma were minor. He was clubbed on the head during a robbery attempt in 1828,<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraph 3582.</ref> was struck by his wife (apparently on multiple occasions),<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraph 3589.</ref> cut his hand with an axe at least once,<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraph 1490.</ref> and incurred frostbite of his feet in 1830-1831.<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraph 930.</ref>
===Body habitus===
The shape ("habitus") of Lincoln's body attracted attention while he was alive, and continues to attract attention today among medical professionals.<ref name="Sotos pages 194-204">[[#Sotos|Sotos, "The Physical Lincoln"]], pages 194-204.</ref> Geneticists are now skeptical of the hypothesis that [[Marfan syndrome]] was the cause of his unusual habitus (see below).
* '''Height''': as a child, Lincoln was tall, describing himself as "though very young, he was large of his age."<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraph 478.</ref> He reached his adult height of 6 feet 4 inches (1.93 m) no later than age 21. * '''Weight''': although well-muscled as a young adult, he was always thin. Questionable evidence says Lincoln weighed over 200 pounds (90 kg) in 1831,<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraph 363.</ref> but this is inconsistent with the emphatic statement of Henry Lee Ross ("The facts are Lincoln never weighed over 175 pounds in his life"),<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraph 368.</ref> the recollection of David Turnham ("weighed about 160 lbs in 1830"),<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraph 361.</ref> and a New Salem neighbor named Camron ("thin as a beanpole and ugly as a scarecrow"). Lincoln's self-reported weight was 180 lbs (81.5 kg) in 1859.<ref>[[#Sotos2|Sotos, "Sourcebook"]], paragraph 369.</ref> He is believed to have weighed even less during his presidency.<ref>[[#White|White]], p. 108.</ref> * '''Marfan syndrome''': based on Lincoln's unusual physical appearance, Dr. Abraham Gordon proposed in 1962 that Lincoln had [[Marfan syndrome]]. Testing Lincoln's [[DNA]] for Marfan syndrome was contemplated in the 1990s, but such a test was not performed.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Abraham Lincoln – a medical appraisal |journal=Kentucky Medical Association |date=March 1962 |issue=60 |pages=249–253 |pmid= 13900423 |last1=Gordon |first1=Abraham M. |volume=60 |issn=0023-0294 |url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/marfansyndrome.html |format=Free full text}} </ref>
: Lincoln's unremarkable [[cardiovascular]] history and his normal visual acuity have been the chief objections to the hypothesis, and today geneticists consider the diagnosis unlikely.<ref>{{cite book |title=Was George Washington Really the Father of Our Country?: A Clinical Geneticist Looks at World History |author=Marion, Robert |publisher=Addison-Wesley |year=1993 |isbn=978-0-201-62255-3 |pages=88–124}} See also: {{cite journal |author=Ready, Tinker |title=Access to presidential DNA denied |journal=[[Nature Medicine]] |year=1999 |volume=5 |issue=8 |page=859 |doi=10.1038/11287|pmid=11645164 }} </ref>
* '''Multiple endocrine neoplasia''': in 2007, Dr. John Sotos proposed that Lincoln had [[multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2b]] (MEN2B).<ref>[[#Sotos|Sotos, "The Physical Lincoln"]].</ref> This hypothesis suggests Lincoln had all the major features of the disease: a marfan-like body shape, large, bumpy lips, [[constipation]], [[hypotonia]], a history compatible with [[cancer]]—to which Sotos ascribes the death of Lincoln's sons [[Edward Baker Lincoln|Eddie]], [[William Wallace Lincoln|Willie]], and [[Tad Lincoln|Tad]], and probably his [[Nancy Hanks Lincoln|mother]]. The "mole" on Lincoln's right cheek, the asymmetry of his face, his large jaw, his drooping eyelid, and "pseudo-depression" are also suggested as manifestations of MEN2B. MEN2B is a genetic disorder, and recently it has been demonstrated that Lincoln's biological mother, [[Nancy Hanks Lincoln]], had many of the same unusual facial features as her son, as well as a marfanoid [[body habitus]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Sotos JG |title=Abraham Lincoln's marfanoid mother: the earliest known case of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B? |journal=Clinical Dysmorphology |volume=21 |issue=3 |pages=131–136 |year=2012 |pmid= 22504423 |doi=10.1097/MCD.0b013e328353ae0c}}</ref> Lincoln's longevity is the principal challenge to the MEN2B hypothesis: Lincoln lived long enough to be assassinated at age 56, while untreated MEN2B is generally understood to result in death by the patient's mid-thirties. There are, however, several reported cases of MEN2B patients surviving into their 50s with no or little treatment. The hypothesis could be proven by DNA testing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/80beats/2009/04/20/scientist-wants-to-test-abraham-lincolns-bloodstained-pillow-for-cancer/ |title=Scientist Wants to Test Abraham Lincoln's Bloodstained Pillow for Cancer |publisher=Discover Magazine |date=April 20, 2009}} {{cite journal |title=Lincoln'd Shroud of Turin |journal=Philadelphia Inquirer |date=April 13, 2009}} </ref>
===Other===
The theory that Lincoln was afflicted with type 5 spinocerebellar [[ataxia]]<ref>{{cite journal |title= Spectrin mutations cause spinocerebellar ataxia type 5 |journal= Nature Genetics |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=184–90 |date=Feb 2006 |pmid=16429157 |doi=10.1038/ng1728 |laysummary=http://mmf.umn.edu/bulletin/spring2006/features/ataxia/ataxia1.cfm |laysource= University of Minnesota Medical Bulletin |laydate= Spring 2006 |last1=Ikeda |first1=Yoshio |last2=Dick |first2=Katherine A. |last3=Weatherspoon |first3=Marcy R. |last4=Gincel |first4= Dan |last5=Armbrust |first5=Karen R. |last6=Dalton |first6=Joline C. |last7=Stevanin |first7=Giovanni |last8=Dürr |first8=Alexandra |last9=Zühlke |first9=Christine |last10=Bürk |first10=Katrin |last11=Clark |first11=H. Brent |last12=Brice |first12=Alexis |last13=Rothstein |first13=Jeffrey D. |last14=Schut |first14=Lawrence J. |last15=Day |first15=John W. |last16=Ranum |first16=Laura P.W. |display-authors=1 |issn= 1061-4036}} </ref> is no longer accepted.<ref>{{cite journal |doi= 10.1212/WNL.0b013e3181bd13c7 |author= Sotos JG. |title= Abraham Lincoln did not have type 5 spinocerebellar ataxia. |journal= Neurology |volume=73 |issue=16 |pages=1328–1332 |year=2009 |pmid= 19841386 |url=http://www.physical-lincoln.com/sca5-and-abraham-lincoln.html }}</ref> The theory that Lincoln's facial asymmetries were a manifestation of [[craniofacial microsomia]]<ref>{{cite journal |doi= 10.1001/archopht.125.8.1126 |author1=Fishman RS |author2=Da Silveira A |title= Lincoln's craniofacial microsomia: three-dimensional laser scanning of 2 Lincoln life masks. |journal= Arch. Ophthalmol. |volume=125 |issue=8 |pages= 1126–1130 |year=2007 |pmid= 17698764 }}</ref> has been replaced with a diagnosis of left synostotic frontal [[plagiocephaly]],<ref name="Sotos pages 194-204"/> which is a type of [[craniosynostosis]].
==Mental health== Lincoln was contemporaneously described as suffering from "[[Melancholia|melancholy]]," a condition which modern mental health professionals would characterize as [[Major depressive disorder|clinical depression]].<ref>{{cite web |publisher=The Atlantic |date=October 2005 |first=Joshua Wolf |last=Shenk |title=Lincoln's Great Depression |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200510/lincolns-clinical-depression |accessdate=2009-10-08}}</ref>
It was during his time as an Illinois legislator that Joshua Speed said Lincoln anonymously published a suicide poem in the Sangamo Journal; though he was not sure of the date, a suicide poem was published on August 25, 1838, making Lincoln 29 years of age. The poem is called ''[[The Suicide's Soliloquy]];'' historians are still divided on whether or not Lincoln was the author.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2004/06/14/040614ta_talk_shenk |author=Joshua Wolf Shenk| date=June 2004 |journal=The New Yorker |title=The Suicide Poem}} </ref>
Whether he may have suffered from depression as a genetic predilection, as a reaction to multiple emotional traumas in his life,<ref>During his life Lincoln experienced the death of multiple close family members, including his mother, his sister, close confidant [[Ann Rutledge]], and two of his sons, [[Edward Baker Lincoln|Eddie]] and [[William Wallace Lincoln|Willie]]. {{cite book |last=Warren |first=Louis Austin |page=175 |isbn=978-0-87195-063-5 |year=1959 |location=Indianapolis |title=: Lincoln's Youth: Indiana Years: Seven to Twenty-One |publisher=Indiana Historical Society Press}}</ref> or a combination thereof is the subject of much current conjecture.<ref>[[#Donald|Donald]], p. 27.</ref>
Lincoln suffered depressed mood after major traumatic events, such as the death of [[Ann Rutledge]] in August 1835,<ref>[[#Donald|Donald]], p. 57.</ref> the cessation of his (purported) engagement to [[Mary Todd Lincoln]] in January 1841 (after which several close associates feared Lincoln's suicide),<ref>[[#Donald|Donald]], p. 88.</ref> and after the [[Second Battle of Bull Run]].<ref>[[#Donald|Donald]], p. 371.</ref> However, it is not clear that any of these episodes meet modern medical criteria for depression.<ref>[[#Sotos|Sotos, "Physical Lincoln"]]. pages 220-233.</ref>
Mary Lincoln felt her husband to be too trusting, and his melancholy tended to strike at times he was betrayed or unsupported by those in whom he put faith.<ref>[[#Schreiner|Schreiner]], p. 154.</ref>
Lincoln would often combat his melancholic moods by delving into works of humor, likely a healthy coping mechanism for his depression.<ref>{{cite book |first=Joshua Wolf |last=Shenk |title=Lincoln's Melancholy: How Depression Challenged a President and Fueled His Greatness |origyear=2005 |year=2006 |isbn=978-0-618-77344-2 |page=116 |publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt |location=New York}}</ref>
It has been proposed that Lincoln took "[[blue mass]]" pills to improve his mood.<ref>{{cite journal |doi= 10.1353/pbm.2001.0048 |author1=Hirschhorn N |author2=Feldman RG |author3=Greaves IA. |title= Abraham Lincoln's blue pills. Did our 16th president suffer from mercury poisoning? |journal= Perspect Biol Med. |volume=44 |issue=3 |pages= 315–322 |year=2001 |pmid= 11482002 }}</ref> There is, however, no support for this in the written record.<ref>[[#Sotos|Sotos, "Physical Lincoln"]], pages 137-139.</ref> (See "Medication" section, below.)
==Medication==
The recollections of Lincoln's legal colleagues (John Stuart, Henry Whitney, Ward Lamon, and William Herndon) all agree that Lincoln took blue mass pills because of [[constipation]]<ref>[[#Sotos2|"Sourcebook"]]. paragraphs 612-626.</ref> (constipation is a troubling symptom in multiple endocrine neoplasia Type 2B, described above). The active ingredient of blue mass is elemental [[mercury (element)|mercury]] – a substance now known to be a neurotoxin in its vaporic state.<ref>[[#Hayden|Hayden]], p. 130.</ref> Whether [[mercury poisoning]] may have affected Lincoln's demeanor before or after he ceased its use in 1861 is unknown, but still remains the subject of conjecture by some historians.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2001/07/0717_lincoln.html |title=Did Mercury in 'Little Blue Pills' Make Abraham Lincoln Erratic? |last=Mayell |first=Hillary |publisher=National Geographic News |date=July 17, 2001 |accessdate=2009-10-12}}</ref> Lincoln's only known assessments of the medication are that it made him "cross" but that he preferred it above others.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://durer.press.illinois.edu/wilson/html/632.html |title=Herndon's Informants |last=Wilson |first=DL |publisher=University of Illinois Press |year=1998 |accessdate=2010-09-22}}</ref>
In 1865, speaking with the Washington correspondent of the [[Pittsburgh Chronicle]], Mrs. Lincoln described an instance in which her husband's "usual medicine," the mercury based "blue pills" made him terribly ill. The correspondent recorded the interview as follows: Mrs. Lincoln "recalled the fact that her husband had been very ill, for several days, from the effects of a dose of blue pills taken shortly before his second inauguration." She said he was not well, and appearing to require his usual medicine, blue pills, she sent to the drug store in which Harrold was employed last and got a dose and gave them to him at night before going to bed, and that next morning his pallor terrified her. 'His face,' said she, pointing to the bed beside which she sat, 'was white as that pillow-case, as it lay just there,' she exclaimed, laying her hand on the pillow—'white, and such a deadly white; as he tried to rise he sank back again quite overcome!' She described his anxiety to be up, there was so much to do, and her persistence and his oppressive languor in keeping him in bed for several days; said he and she both thought it so strange that the pills should affect him in that way; they had never done so before, and both concluded they would get no more medicine there, as the attendant evidently did not understand making up prescriptions."<ref>California Digital Newspaper Collection – Late Atlantic Intelligence, Sacramento Daily Union, Volume 29, Number 4497, 21 August 1865</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== {{Refbegin}}
*<cite id="Donald">{{cite book |first=David Herbert |last=Donald |title=Lincoln |location=New York |publisher=Simon and Schuster |year=1996 |origyear=1995 |isbn=978-0-684-82535-9}} *<cite id="Hayden">{{cite book |title=Pox: Genius, Madness, and the Mysteries of Syphilis |isbn=978-0-465-02881-8 |last=Hayden |first=Deborah |publisher=Perseus Publishing |year=2003 |location=New York }} *<cite id="Schreiner">{{cite book|title=The Trials of Mrs. Lincoln |last=Schreiner |first=Samuel Agnew |publisher=University of Nebraska Press |year=2005 |origyear=1987 |isbn=978-0-8032-9325-0}} *<cite id="Sotos">{{cite book|title=The Physical Lincoln |last=Sotos |first=John G. |publisher= Mt. Vernon Book Systems |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-9818193-2-7}} *<cite id="Sotos2">{{cite book|title=The Physical Lincoln Sourcebook |last=Sotos |first=John G. |publisher= Mt. Vernon Book Systems |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-9818193-3-4}} Full-text index [http://www.physical-lincoln.com/sbindex.html here]. *<cite id="White">{{cite book |last=White, Jr. |first=Ronald C. |title=A. Lincoln: A Biography |publisher=Random House, Inc. |year=2009 |isbn= 978-1-4000-6499-1}}
{{Abraham Lincoln}}
